Student Government is in the middle of spring elections, end-of-the-year trip planning and the Special Olympics skating trip. Senior Codi Ziolkowski, secretary, is planning a trip to the Dover Skating Rink for Special Olympics, where CSG members can interact with the kids.

Campaigns are underway for students to take over class and CSG officer positions. Senior Tyler Walters, CSG vice-president, is organizing the spring elections and the induction ceremony of the new class and CSG officers for the 2014-2015 school year.

The Hope Tote project, led by CSG historian, senior Sai Kodali, successfully collected 2,938 hygiene products to be donated to the Sunday Breakfast Mission.

The CSG also will be put on the annual Easter egg hunt for preschool and lower school students. Led by senior Shivani Joshi, CSG president, the event will consist of a meet and greet with the Easter bunny and an egg hunt.

Junior Mike Zerillo, CSG sergeant-in-arms, is preparing for the end-of-year trip to Hershey Park, Pa., which will kick off summer with a day of fun for upper school students.

Shivani Joshi

Fairwinds Christian

The Second Pack the Place was held April 15. More people came out than at the previous event, hosted by the Student Body Council.

Progress reports were sent out on April 17. Parents can view their child's progress reports on Renweb.

Fairwinds currently is on spring break. Classes resume Monday, which is when the class of 2014 will go on its senior trip.

Graduation is fast approaching for seniors on May 22 and the kindergarden graduation is the week after.

Students and staff our reminded of the school verse, Psalm 25:5: "Lead me in thy truth, and teach me; for thou art the God of my salvation, on thee do I wait all the day!

People can follow the school on Instagram – @FCSKnights – and like it on Facebook, Fairwinds Christian School.

Kara Gallaher

Padua

On April 10, at the Fifth Annual Dinner in Honor of Women's Achievement, Padua Academy announced the creation of the Father Roberto Balducelli Scholarship Fund. Strictly need-based, the scholarship fund is aimed at providing a transformational education to young women who otherwise could not attend Padua Academy.

Leigh Anne Tuohy, the inspiration behind the movie "The Blind Side" and 2014 Padua honoree, pledged $1,000 to the fund which joins the generosity of Barbra Frank Andrisani who kicked-off the scholarship with a pledge of $10,000.

The World Languages Department hosted "That French Show" on April 15 in Roberto Hall. The afternoon included French Trivia with prizes, a Tour of Paris, and an assortment of short skits, en Français, of course!

More than 30 students participated in the State History Day contest at Delaware Technical Community College on April 12, coming home with several awards:

In the senior group website category, Erin Spadaccini, Abigail Strusowski and Lauren Davis won second place for "Responsibility on Trial: The State of Israel vs. Adolf Eichmann." This project advances to the national contest.

In the individual website category, Padua earned first, second and third place: Colleen Murray's "No Irish Need Apply: Molly's Fights for Rights" placed third; Rebecca Bolten's "The Espionage Act of 1917: A Responsible Restriction of Rights" placed second, and Helena Bush's "The Community Mental Health Act: Journey to Deinstitutionalization" placed first. Rebecca and Helena's projects will advance to the national contest.

In the senior group exhibit category, Megan Henry and Kristen Knaide won a special award from the University of Delaware for "Out of the Shadows." Also in this category, Maggie Cunningham, Breanna Reyes and Sarah Lang won the Delaware History Award; Taylor Urbanic won third place and Kary Santayana took second place. Kary's project advances to the national contest.

Dana Caracci won third in the performance category for "Blacklisted in Hollywood: The Story of Lee Grant."

In the individual documentary category, Deborah Whiteman won second for "Fighting for Women Suffrage" and Laura Tomlinson won first for her documentary "The Right to Security: Fort Miles and Coastal Protection During WWII." Both will advance to the national contest.

On April 11, the senior class gathered for retreat with the help of Sarah Hart, a nationally recognized Catholic singer/songwriter. The theme for the day was "Beginning Again: Be Who You Are and Be That Well." Hart spoke to the students about the strength of women and their friendships and shared stories of women in scripture who supported one another in faith and friendship. Throughout the day, the students had fun singing along to "Lean on Me" and "You've Got a Friend in Me."

On April 12, students joined Bishop Malooly and 800 young people from the Diocese of Wilmington to witness their faith and carry the Pilgrimage cross through the streets of Wilmington. The event is organized by the Diocesan Youth Leadership Team which includes Padua students Lara Ballintyn, Daria Chicosky, Bridget Fassano, Ashley Muschiatti and Imani Scott.

Seventeen students and members of the Jazz Band performed to a packed house during this year's "Night at the Queen," April 8 at The Queen in downtown Wilmington.

Junior Abby Strusowski won the 2014 Common Wealth Awards student essay contest and joined two other area students at a black tie gala to meet sportscaster Bob Costas, actress Anjelica Huston and baseball player Mariano Rivera on April 5. Abby's essay illustrated her appreciation for the work of Costas.

Nikki Rash

Red Lion Christian

On March 11, art students competed in the ACSI Fine Arts Festival. Senior Hannah Lee won first place in her category, along with a blue ribbon. Blue ribbons also were awarded to senior Christina Bansbach, freshman Abigail Tokarski and a second one to Lee for a separate piece. Red ribbons were awarded to Christina Bansbach, Justin Hazewski, Jonathan Huey, Laura Rogerson, Maddison Tracy, Brianna Magee, Alexandra Butera and Yufei Liu. White ribbons were awarded to Rachel Schmitz, Alexis Day and Victor Kim.

On March 26, students from Tom Berry's marketing class competed in the Diamond Challenge for Business Entrepreneurs. The students who attended were Cole Boulanger, Nathan Campbell, Colton Herbein, Jisoo Hong, Victor Kim, Daniel Mihalko, Rachel No, Bradley Sewell and Katelyn Shoemaker. They were one of four winners in the preliminary round, and advanced to compete in the state final.

Nicki Pizzulli

Salesianum

The Salesians for Life Club recently held a bake sale, raising more than $250 for the Bayard House of Wilmington, a house for underprivileged mothers who have chosen life over abortion. The Bayard House aids these women financially and provides them with necessities the mothers may lack.

The Model UN team competed in the Second Annual HENMUN: University of Delaware Model UN Conference, over the course of three days. Eighteen schools from all over the Northeast region participated. Results include Liam Haffey, honorable mention, "Ethiopia, Disarmament and Security Council"; Daniel Donaher, outstanding delegate, Netherlands, Social/Humanitarian Council; Justin McCartney, honorable mention, Minister of Finance, Joint Crisis Committee: Ottoman Empire; John Mathew, best delegate, Netherlands, Disarmament and Security Council.

Salesianum hosted on April 8 the criminal justice panel "Crime & Conscience." Moderated by Chief Justice of the Delaware Supreme Court Leo Strine, the panel explored the intersection of duty and public service with personal values and conscience. Other topics included the death penalty and the role of race in the criminal justice system. Panelists consisted of Public Defender for the State of Delaware Brendan O'Neill, State Prosecutor for the Delaware Department of Justice Kathleen M Jennings and Commissioner of the Delaware Department of Correction Robert Coupe. The panel provided a fascinating forum for students from the Debate Club and Mock Trial Team to consider the role of the morality in the careers they are considering.

Stephen Ryan

Sanford

Earlier this month, many Sanford students were recognized and inducted into the Cum Laude Society and World Language Honor societies. The World Language Honor Societies recognize talent in one of the three languages taught at Sanford: Spanish, French and Latin. The Cum Laude Society inductees are students who have maintained a grade point average in the top 20 percent of their class, with no more than 10 percent being inducted at a time. Seniors Christopher Malafronti, Jason Conti, Jia Liu, Nate Reynolds and Anton Vasilyev were inducted. Juniors Trevor Schlack, Xiaoxi Wang, Trevor Long, Zihan Ling, Meera Ghandi and Kelsey Mendell were inducted into the Cum Laude Society.

Also, this month marked Sanford's first student-led conferences. Replacing parent-teacher conferences, these meetings had students and their parents coming to school to discuss courses for next year with their adviser and to reflect on their academic year so far. This initiative was implemented across both the middle school and upper school.

On Monday and Tuesday, the middle and upper schools art show will be held in the Stephen May Commons and the Tower. Art students from both divisions will have their works on display for their peers to admire.

The annual auction is Saturday. The theme of the evening, "Rock the Queen," comes from the venue, World Cafe Live at the Queen. Proceeds will go toward renovating Geipel Auditorium to convert the space into a state-of-the-art performing arts theater and classrooms. The new auditorium will replace the former gymnasium as a testament to the flourishing performing arts program at Sanford.

Bryan McLellan

St. Elizabeth

A prayer labyrinth was set up in the St. E Center lobby during Holy Week. Students were able to participate in the prayer experience during the school day and the labyrinth was open to parents, parishioner, and friends on the evening of April 16.

Students were invited to join the Youth Ministry Group on April 17 for its first Holy Thursday High School Lock-Out. The evening began with a light dinner in Grant Hall followed by Holy Thursday Mass in St. Elizabeth Church. Following Mass, the students boarded a bus to visit local churches and participated in a scavenger hunt to discover unique elements on the tour.

Plans are being made for the third Project Spain initiative, scheduled for fall 2014. St. Elizabeth will welcome 20 high school students and their teachers from Colegio Mater Dei in Castellon de la Plana, Spain, for a 10-day homestay with St. E families in September. In the spring of 2015, St. E students will visit their new friends in Spain and tour Madrid and Andalucia.

Senior Sabrina Hackendorn and freshman Alanna Speaks were honored at a luncheon sponsored by the Delaware Women's Alliance for Sport and Fitness on April 6. Sabrina received recognition as a DWASF Outstanding Female Athlete who ranks in the top third of her class; portrays the qualities of dedication, leadership, and sportsmanship; and who participates in sports at least two seasons per academic year. She also received the Senior Scholarship Award for the outstanding female athlete in the northern part of the state. Alanna was named a SWASF Athlete of Promise as a ninth or tenth grade female athlete who excels in academics; has begun to portray qualities of dedication, leadership, and sportsmanship; and who participates in sports at least one season per academic year.

Today and Friday are snow make-up days.

The annual Peer Tutoring Mass and Breakfast will take place on Tuesday.

The Diocese of Wilmington's St. Francis de Sales Awards Convocation, which recognizes outstanding Catholic school seniors, will take place on Wednesday at Holy Family Church. Bishop Malooly will preside.Seniors being honored are Sabrina Hackendorn, Jack Harkins, Jesse McCann, Maddie Rizzo, Matthew Rydlewski, Owen Stecca, Donovan Sweeney, Sarah Todaro, Michael Whiting and Patricia Worthy.

Vincent DeLissio

St. Mark's

The Spring Open House: A Snapshot of Saint Mark's will be held from 6:30 to 8 p.m. May 1. It is for students in fifth-, sixth- and seventh-grades and their parents. For more information, contact Matthew Evans, director of admissions, at 757-8721.

Students in the Aquinas Program swept the Senior Group Documentary category for the second year in a row at the 2014 Delaware History Day Competition on April 12 at Delaware Technical Community College's Stanton campus. First and second place winners will compete at the National History Day competition at the University of Maryland June 15-19.

Results included: first place, juniors Andrew Kacmarcik, Tina Nguyen, Lauren Crouse and Devin DeTurk for "Influence of Technology on Privacy & Rights and Responsibilities of Privacy." Second, juniors Annie Estes, Katie Lee, Andrea Ludman and Caitlin Mannering for the documentary "Mental Healthcare: The Evolution of Care and Treatment." Third, juniors Dylan Colby, Regine Choi, Zachary Irons and Alex Wolff for the documentary "The Role of Social Media in Revolution."

The Aquinas Scholars seminar for honor students is currently taught by Holly Bryk and Dennis Schaff, who oversaw the students' projects.

Senior Lauren Johnson will receive the St. Timothy National Award for Outstanding Young People by the Catholic Diocese of Wilmington's Office for Catholic Youth and Young Adult Ministry. Johnson will be honored on May 6 at the Rollins Center at Dover Downs. This is the highest possible recognition from the National Federation for Catholic Youth Ministry.

Senior track standout Zach Schmelz continues his assault on the track and field record books. On April 12 Schmelz led the boys' track & field team to a win at the Caravel Invitational against 18 other teams, and set three new school records in the process, bringing his indoor and outdoor track school record total to nine. In the 400 meter dash, Schmelz clocked a time of 48.36 seconds, breaking the school record he set last year. This ranks him 11th all-time in state history and 39th in the country this season. In the 200 meter dash, he ran 22.10 seconds, also a new school record. Schmelz and fellow seniors Mike Catalano and T.J. Brown and junior Papa Otchere-Addo broke the school record for the 4x200 meter relay. Their time of 1:29.45 is ranked number one in the state.

Senior Jenna Fannon was awarded Delaware Women's Alliance for Sport and Fitness Outstanding Female Athletes Award and sophomore Madison Burnham was awarded Athlete of Promise Award.

Junior Artrell Flonnory has been appointed as the webmaster of the Capital District of Key Club, International. Flonnery was chosen out of approximately 20 candidates to manage all Capital District social media, including Facebook, Twitter, and the district website. Flonnery is vice president of Key Club.

The Key Club chapter also represented the school well at the 2014 Capitol District Convention, held March 21-23 in Baltimore. The club was recognized for its extraordinary participation in the Governor's Project and Project Eliminate, both Kiwanis programs, as they were in the top 10 out of 5,000 Key Clubs internationally for the amount of funds they raised. Sophomore Emma Johnson sang the national anthem to open the convention. Junior Dylan Colby was honored as a Distinguished Club president and junior Artrell Flonnery was honored as a Distinguished Club vice president. Sophomores Anna Shields was recognized as the member of the month awardee and Katya Monarski received honorable mention for her Impromptu written essay. Colby also was elected as the lieutenant governor of the Capital District.

Senior Miranda Murdoch is the recipient of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the U.S. Voice of Democracy Certificate of Merit for her entry in the organization's Patriotic Audio Essay Contest. Murdoch was presented with the award in school on March 7 by Commander Joseph Copes of VFW Post 838 in Port Penn. Her essay centered on the contest's theme "Why I'm Optimistic About Our Nation's Future." The award designates Murdoch as an "Outstanding Spokesperson for Freedom," and she was given a medal and a special coin in addition to a monetary award.

Jake Bertleson

Tatnall

Even though National Decision Day – the admissions deadline for high school seniors to make their college decision – isn't for another week, seniors are showing their college spirit this month. Members of the senior class have been accepted to 118 colleges, with more than 200 total acceptances to-date. Universities include Yale, Wake Forrest, College of Charleston, Southern California, Pennsylvania State, New York and Delaware. As students make their decision, they are encouraged to wear T-shirts and sweat shirts from their university to show their school spirit and pride.

Earlier this month, the AP psychology class traveled to Towson, Md., to present its original research at the only AP psychology conference in the United States. The trip was a huge success, and the students were recognized and given a certificate by the American Psychological Association.

Students will perform "The Velveteen Rabbit" in the annual Drama Club production on May 2. Melanie Altemus and Savannah Harrow are directing the children's show, while Talia Kramer and Benjamin von Duyke are playing the lead roles of Andrew and the Rabbit. The production will take place in the Laird Performing Arts Center at 7:30 p.m. The production is a one-night event.

Spring Day 2014 "A Day at the Races" is slated for Saturday. The Tatnall tradition includes games, raffles, food and entertainment.

Savannah Harrow

Tower Hill

On April 11 and 13, the upper school drama department held their spring production,"You Can't Take It With You." The romantic comedy was centered around Alice Vanderhof, played by senior Rachel League; Tony Kirby, played by senior Bradley Pedano, and their very different families. This was the final play for eight seniors, including Cole Wenzel, Mark Christy, Courtney Hayman, Jaimie Manlove, Julia Reith, Bradley Pedano, Rachel League and Rodney Orr.

The eighth-grade teams captured first and second place in the region in the Delaware Math League Competition. At the individual level, Catherine An placed first and Hudson Pepper placed second. Students competed in the statewide competition on April 1. Adviser is Beth Anderson and eighth-graders participating included Catherine An, Bo Anderson, Renee Albrecht, Rand Barton, Caroline Elson, Jaanvi Mehta, Brian Miller, Jasmine Minhas, Hannah Nash, Hudson Pepper, Allison L. Smith and Max Williamson.

The 10th- to 12th-grade Math League teams placed fourth, fifth and seventh in the region. The "A" team qualified and participated in the invitational meet held in Dover on March 31. The team was led by seniors Jimmy Damewood, Carina Miller and Sophie Xue, along with junior Andrew Lin and sophomore Graham Pepper. Adviser was Noreen Jordan.

On April 5, fifth- and sixth-grade Science Olympiad teams, under the direction of coaches Marie-Vayo Greenbaum and Timothy Weymouth, competed at St. Marks school against more than 400 students from 22 independent and parochial schools. The team won 14 medals in eight different events.

Also on April 5, the Jefferson Awards club was awarded a Gold Banner. A presentation made by seniors Zach Nitsche and Sam Murphy gained the club enough points for a gold award.

The Home and School Association spring bake sale will be held 7:30 to 8:30 a.m. May 2. It will be at the school's main entrance and in the lower school courtyard. Any home-cooked or store-bought baked goods that could be donated would be appreciated. Please label any food that is nut free, gluten free or dairy free.

Spencer Johnson

Ursuline

On April 8, the eighth annual Great Painting Caper took place. Seventeen paintings were hidden within the recesses of the academy and 14 already have been recovered safely and returned to upper school art teacher Erin McNichol. Each year, Studio Art students research a stolen masterpiece and reproduce the work as accurately as possible. The students then hide the work within the upper school and engage the student body in a game of hide and seek. The goal of the Great Painting Caper is to spotlight the high incidence and travesty of art theft around the world.

Senior Valerie Quiñones has been selected by the Diocese of Wilmington's Office of Youth Ministry to receive the distinguished St. Timothy National Youth Award, for her outstanding work both in school and in her parish's youth ministry program.

Senior Caitlyn Scully has been chosen to receive the St. Timothy National Award for Outstanding Young People. This is the highest recognition from the National Federation for Catholic Youth Ministry. A diocese can confer this honor upon a student who sets a positive example for other youth and demonstrates service to others and Christian leadership in parish, school, and/or community settings.

Junior Leslie Collins has been admitted to the Juniper Institute for Young Writers at the University of Massachusetts. This summer, she will work with University of Massachusetts professors and published authors to refine her writing skills in fiction and poetry.

Sophomore Midori Lofton has been admitted to the Pre-College Summer Program at New York University.

The Jefferson Awards Students in Action team announced the following winners for outstanding community service: Carly Volko, for her work with the Delaware Association for the Blind; Ryann Sutera, for her work with Teens Against Poverty and service work in Haiti; Emma Derr, for designing and constructing a handicap accessible picnic table at a local park for her Girl Scout Silver Award; Erin Davis, for her work with Beebe Hospital and Charlotte Moore, for dedicating her birthday to several service organizations for several years.

Classes will resume Monday.

Elizabeth Coniglio

Wilmington Christian

On April 12, school winners competed in the Delaware History Day contest at Delaware Technical Community College. Students participated in the junior and senior divisions under the leadership of faculty members Trey Speers, Sharon Duncan, Cheryl Schultz and Sara Magarahan.

In the senior division, Peter Tuttle placed first for his individual exhibit "Rwanda Genocide." Peter also won a special prize from the Delaware Historical Society for his research. The award for first place group exhibit went to Kaylene Mummert and Sarah Rettig for "The Holocaust: Rights and Responsibilities of Christians." Joy Eleutheriou was awarded a prize from the University of Delaware for her research on child labor reform. Jacob Conrad, Jeremy Ewing, Luke Muller, Derek Needham and Nathan Volz won third for their website on Jackie Robinson.

In the junior division, Andrew Dingwall was awarded first for his research paper "The Un-United Kingdom." Nick Kater's exhibit "No Taxation without Representation" won first place. The prize for best individual website was won by Ryan Albrecht for his "Trail of Tears" research. Christina Bourantas won second for her "Miranda vs. Arizona" exhibit.

The DuPont Co. awarded a special prize to Christian Reilly for his documentary on the company, which also won second place statewide in the documentary category. Christian also won an award from the Hagley Museum for having the best project featuring American industry.

This week is Easter break and classes will resume Monday.

A.J. Stiles

Wilmington Friends

"EdcampDE 2014," the first such program in Delaware for teachers, will be held Saturday. Edcamps, which started about five years ago, are based "on principles of connected and participatory learning." The idea is to bring teachers together and let them decide on their agenda, building discussions around what is most important to them. Lower school teachers Brian Fahey and Chris Loeffler have led the organizational effort at Friends.

On Tuesday morning, Head of Lower School Annette Hearing and the first-grade lead teachers will host program for parents of current kindergarten and pre-first students. Also on Tuesday, the Quaker Closet quality re-sale shop will be open to the public, 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m.

The spring concert season kicks off Tuesday evening, with the upper school instrumental concert directed by Christopher Verry. The upper school choral concert follows on Wednesday evening, with ensembles directed by Margaret Anne Butterfield.

Next week's trips include the fifth-grade overnight to Washington; the sixth-grade trip to the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology; and the upper school Quakerism classes' visits to Centre Meeting.

Led by the Gay Straight Alliance, Friends participated in the National Day of Silence on April 11. The event calls attention to "the silencing effect of anti-LGBT bullying and harassment in schools." Students and faculty participated by wearing a rainbow ribbon and remaining silent for the day, or, for those who had obligations that would not allow them to be silent, by wearing a lavender ribbon to show support for the effort. Seniors Mitchell Juers and Molly Marcus co-clerk the GSA committee, and director of college guidance Kathleen Martin is the faculty adviser.

Julia Rhodes

search_result.title: Meet the other students nominated as Central Jersey Academic All ...
search_result.text:
Natasha Mascarenhas

@NMASC_

They are on the honor roll. They are class valedictorians. They volunteer in the churches and in hospitals. They play sports and are members of science clubs and bands.

The other 23 students nominated for the 2016 Academic All-Star program have accomplished much in their lives and have more to do. While the program's judges could only choose the top 11, the other nominees are highly successful and passionate, too.

Read on to see what mean. Their profiles include a selection of their school and outside activities, honors and achievements, and a nominator comment. They are listed in alphabetical order.

READ: LOOK and WATCH: Our Class of 2016 graduation coverage

READ: Education coverage from around Central Jersey

READ: Advice from our College Connection columnist

Aidan Benderly

School: Middlesex County Academy, Metuchen

School activities: Academy soccer, varsity member; National Honor Society, president; Future Business Leaders of America, member; Math league, member.

Outside activities: Metuchen Marching Band,Jazz Band and Indoor Drumline, Section Leader; Hub City Fencing, member.

Honors and achievements: National Honor Society; Hub City Fencing, regional and national ranking; Qualifier and Competitor at 2015 Junior Olympic Fencing Championships; 2016 NJSIAA Scholar/Athlete Award; First place at 2016 TIA Chapter X Indoor Winds Championship

Nominator comment: “Aidan is a multi-season athlete who is the epitome of sportsmanship. He is a genuine young man who as a student, National Honor Society President and member of several teams, continuously demonstrates trust, fairness and solid leadership.” - Kelly Nakielny, school counselor.

Daniel Castro

School: New Brunswick High School

School activities: National Honor Society, vice president; National Art Honor Society, president; Varsity Bowling, member; Future Business Leaders of America, vice president; Peer leadership, member.

Outside activities: Office of Diversity & Academic Success in the Sciences, a Division of Life Science at Rutgers University; member.

Honors and achievements: AP Scholar; 2015 Consumer Bowl County Champions; New Jersey Association of Teachers of Japan Achievement Award

Nominator comment: “Daniel is a well rounded student. His greatest strength is his ability to participate in various school activities, but still excel in his academics.” - Erica Jeria, school counselor.

Joseph Chiusano

School: Old Bridge High School

School activities: Student Senate, president; Student Council, president; Old Bridge Cross Country, athlete; Old Bridge Track and Field, captain; President's council, member/head; Italian Club, member; Middle States Accrediation Team, head student representative; Peer, student; Red Cross, member; Pre-Med club, member

Outside activities: St. Judges Ranch for kids, collector and donor; Madison Center Nursing Home, volunteer.

Honors and achievements: Old Bridge Knight Star for Academic, School Spirit and Community Service; Senior Superlative for Most School Spirit, most likely to Do the Right Thing; Old Bridge Track Team Captain of Long, Triple and High jumpers

Nominator comment: “Joseph is reliable, optimistic, self-motivated and loyal.. He is, without a doubt, one of the top leaders in our school. After a brief conversation with him, one would immediately recognize that he bears maturity beyond his years. This maturity is infectious and he instills motivation amongst those around him. “ Vincent Sasso, principal.

Jessica Clark

School: Middlesex High School

School activities: Varsity Cross Country, captain; Varsity Track and Field, captain; Chorus, first soprano; Academic team, Captain; School Musical, lead role

Outside activities: Nursing home volunteer; Piano; Do Something Club, member.

Honors and achievements: Valedictorian; School Record Holder Varsity Track and Field 3200m; School Record Holder Varsity Cross Country; Cross Country All Division; Hugh O'Brian Youth Leadership Delegate; Westminster Choir College Delegate for Piano.

Nominator comment: “Jessica is by far one of the most intelligent, driven, motivated, hard-working students that I have ever encountered. On top of the being so active, she is also extremely friendly, personable and out-going. She has one of the sweetest demeanors that I know, and no matter how hectic her schedule is she always manages to keep a smile on her face.” - Dawn Siegle, school counselor.

Michael Corace

School: Spotswood High School, Spotswood

School activities: Track and Field, captain; National Honor Society, president; class government, treasurer.

Honors and achievements: Spotswood High School Athlete of the Season; GMC Division All-Star Team; GMC Academic Varsity Award.

Nominator comment: “What sets Michael apart from other students is his unwavering determination to learn and succeed whether that is in academics or athletics.” - Lauren Knapp, school counseling department chair.

Theodore Coursen

School: Colonia High School, Colonia

School activities: Track, member; Newspaper, editor.

Outside activity: National Fallen Firefighters Memorial Foundation; member.

Honors and achievements: Spanish Honor Society; Quill & Scroll Honor Society.

Nominator comment: “Theodore is a very conscientious and hardworking student. He also is involved in the community and works a part-time job.” - Cheryl Galvin, counselor.

Mary Dahl

School: Piscataway High School

School activities: Marching Band, student leader; Improv Troupe, president; Tri-M Music Honor Society, treasurer, National Honor Society. member; Math League, member.

Outside Activity: Girl Scouts; member.

Honors and achievements: 2015 Continental Calculus League, highest average; Girl Scouts Community Service Bar

Nominator comment: “Mary is a young lady whose dedication and commitment are exceptional. Her transcript clearly illustrates her drive toward academics. However whether it be hours of practice for Marching Band, hours of rehearsal for the school musical, or hours of volunteer service for Girl Scouts, Mary gives her best to everything.” - Pamela Travis, school counselor.

Sydney DeVoe

South Amboy High School

School activities: Cross Country, captain; Winter Track, captain; Spring Track, captain; Student Council, secretary; Honor Society, member.

Outside activity: YMCA Swim Team, captain.

Honors and achievements: National Honor Society; Honor Roll.

Nominator comment: “I can’t think of a more worthy student. Sydney is proof that this generation is good and caring for the future. She is a true scholar athlete.” - Joy Przywara, school counselor.

Cristel Galindo

School: Middlesex County Vocational-Technical High School, Piscataway

School activities: Interact Club, event manager; National Technical Honor Society, member; Spanish honor Society, member.

Outside activity: Postpartum Unit in Trinitas Hospital, volunteer.

Honors and achievements: Recognition for the National Technical Honor Society.

Nominator comment: “Cristel’s executive skills in managing change, self-regulation and time-management are her strengths. Cristel is not intimidated to actively seek help!” - Judith Harkay, school counselor.

Lesley Martinez Garcia

School: New Brunswick Health Sciences Technology High School

School activities: Varsity Tennis, member; National Art Honor Society; After School Tutor.

Outside activities: Rutgers 4-H Teen council Leadership club, climate change ambassador; Office of Assemblyman Danielson, intern; Office of Diversity & Academic Success in the Sciences, student; Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital, volunteer; New Brunswick Free Public Library, volunteer.

Nominator comment: “Lesley is a hard working, determined young woman who has overcome numerous obstacles in her life. She dreams of entering health professions so she can give back to society.” - Colleen White, school counselor.

Isabella Guzzi

School: Dunellen High School

School activities: National Honor Society, secretary; Class Student Council, president; Varsity Cheerleading, captain; Varsity Basketball; Varsity Softball; Spanish club, member; Math League; Biology Club, Peer Leaders, member; Safety ambassadors, member.

Outside activities: Girl Scouts, ambassador; CCD assistant teacher; salsa classes.

Honors and achievements: National Honor Society; New Jersey Girls State, delegate; 2012 Math League award; 4 year High Honor Roll.

Nominator comment: “Bella’s major purpose in life is to serve others. She is one of the most selfless people I have ever known.” Al Trafford, guidance counselor.

Akhil Gumidyala

School: Montgomery High School

School activities: School Newspaper, editor; Red Cross Club.

Honors and achievements: Given Honor Roll status six times

Nominator comment: “Akhil is kind, motivated and responsible. Akhil is passionate about Journalism.” - Jessica Ritson, school counselor.

Nino Hervias

School: Carteret High School

School activities: World Language Honor Society; CHS Drama club; CHS Marching Band.

Outside activities: Karate.

Honors and achievements: Student of the Month award; World Language Honor Society.

Nominator comment: “Nino has been reported as being the highest achieving student currently in the Italian Language Program at Carteret High School. He is an exemplary student who is enthusiastic, open-minded and intelligent.”- Dara Benjamin, guidance counselor.

Morgan McCord

School: Voorhees High School, Glen Gardner

School activities: Key Club, president; Honor Society, peer tutor; World Language Honor Society; Mu Alpha Theta Mathematics Honor Society; Wind Ensemble, first chair; concert Band, first chair; Swimming; Lacrosse; Field Hockey.

Outside activities: Girl Scouts; Hunterdon County Summer Nature Program, assistant camp counselor; TCNJ Honors Wind Ensemble.

Honors and achievements: Academic High Honor Roll; Wesleyan University Book Award; The President’s volunteer Service Award; AP Scholar with Distinction; AP Scholar Award.

Nominator comment: “Morgan is not the average student that you meet every day. She is truly a special young lady, and it only takes a minute after meeting her to realize this. I can tell you that whatever is next for her, she will be great.” - Jessica Gorton, Gifted and Talented program coordinator.

Catherine Miller

School: Middlesex County Academy for Allied Health and Biomedical Sciences

School activities: Basketball; Softball; Student Council, president; Cultural Diversity Club, secretary; Senior-Freshmen mentoring.

Outside activities: Marketing Internship; Muay Thai/Mixed Martial Arts.

Honors and achievements: School delegate to district prom committee; chairperson for Senior-Freshmen mentoring program.

Nominator comment: “Cassie is one of the strongest organizations that I have ever seen in my 25 year career. She is able to organize and execute an idea or program to the success of her goals.”- Michael W. Fanelli, principal.

Victoria Morin

School: The Pingry School, Bernards

School activities: Writing Center, head coordinator; Student Technology Committee, communications leader; Polyglot Language Magazine, editor, ECLC, special needs tutor.

Outside activities: Ashita-Tomorrow (NPO), volunteer; tutor.

Honors and achievements: Cum Laude Society, Scholarship Prize, New Jersey Governor’s School of Engineering and Technology Scholar; AP Scholar with Honor; National Merit Commended Student; Honor Roll.

Nominator comment: “A top student in her class, Victoria Morin possesses an innate curiosity about the world, and quietly capitalizes on opportunities not only to learn as much as she can but also to contribute as much as she can.” - Dr. Denise Brown-Allen, upper school director.

Margaret Nugent

School: Delaware Valley Regional High School, Frenchtown

School activities: Cross Country, captain; National Honor Society, recording secretary; Mock Trial; Stage Crew; Best Buddies.

Outside activities: DVAA Travel Softball.

Honors and achievements: Varsity Letter; Distinguished Honor Roll; Top PSAT score.

Nominator comment: “Her logical mind and pragmatism. I don’t know that I have ever seen Maggie get her feathers ruffled, she is very calm and methodical in her approach to her work.” -Kristina Sterbenc, counselor.

Nishi Patel

School: John P. Stevens High School, Edison

School activities: Student Council, vice president; Odyssey of the Mind; Hawks; National Honor Society; English Honor Society; spanish Honor Society.

Outside activities: JFK Medical Center, volunteer.

Honors and achievements: AP Scholar with distinction; Presidential Education award; 2016 First Place States Odyssey of the Mind.

Nominator comment: “Most notably, though, is Nishi’s innate optimism. Even when material or situations get difficult, she does not allow herself to get defeated. Instead, she sees it was an opportunity to prove to herself that she can master the material or situation rather than letting it master her. This outlook is a wonderful characteristic to have both as a student as as a person.” - Lisa Lin, school counselor.

Saloni Patel

School: Sayreville War Memorial High School

School activities: Science club, lab coordinator; Acts of Kindness, treasurer; National honor society; corresponding secretary; Science National Honor Society, vice president.

Outside activities: Parlin Dental, shadowing; Sayre Public Library, summer volunteer; National Academics Future Physicians Organization, delegate; Girls State New Jersey (Under American Legion Auxiliary), delegate.

Honors and achievements: 2015 Student Recognition Award; Class of 2016 Valedictorian; 2016 NJ DECA Regional Marketing and Communications finalist

Nominator comment: “In conversation with Saloni she credits her family and the values they have instilled in her for her success. Her wish is to “be half as selfless and possess half the character they possess.” - James J. Brown, principal.

Tricia Raquepo

School: South River High School

School activities: National Honor Society, president; Student Council, president; Varsity Tennis, captain; Varsity Cheer, captain.

Outside activities: Relay for Life, team member; South River Cheer Camp, captain; Tutor.

Honors and achievements: Ranked first in the class; Honor Roll; Senior Student of the Month; Coach’s Award for Varsity Tennis

Nominator comment: “In my opinion, Tricia Raquepo’s greatest strength is leadership.” Dawn Sutphin, guidance counselor.

Kyle Veltre

School: Bishop George Ahr High School, Edison

School activities: National Honor Society; Peer Leadership, leader; Varsity Soccer, captain; CASC, member.

Outside activities: U.S. Parma Soccer Club, player; Cathy’s Coat Drive, leader.

Honors and achievements: Rutgers Zimmerman Writing Award; Varsity Letter; Top 10 percent of graduating class; Distinguished Honors.

Nominator comment: “Kyle’s leadership is his greatest strength. He excels in the classroom, on the soccer field, and in all of the clubs he joins.” -Denise Markert, school counselor.

Leah Womelsdorf

School: Union County Vocational-Technical High School, Scotch Plains

School activities: National Honor Society, vice president; Math League, president; Class Council, treasurer; Technology Department, technology intern, Student Government, treasurer.

Outside activities: NJ Governor's STEM Scholars; Relay for Life; Girl Scouts of America; Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School Varsity Cross Country, Winter Track and Spring Track.

Honors and achievements: Vo-Tech Student of the Month; High Honor Roll; National Honor Society member; Scotch Plains-Fanwood High School course Record Greystone Park cross-country.

Nominator comment: “Leah is highly intelligent and really loves learning. She is also a real team player and loves to help others. She is a real standout at our school.” Jeffrey Lerner, school principal.

Michael Wong

School: Somerville High School

School activities: Junior Class Officers, president; Marching Band ,Alto Sax Section leader; Pioneer Studios, anchor and director; National Honor Society; Interact Club, vice president.

Outside activities: Taekwondo; American Cancer Society; Relay for Life.

Honors and achievements: Award for exemplary volunteerism from Bridgewater Relay for Life; honorary member Branchburg Rotary Club member; slated to attend Bioconnect oncology leadership development program.

Nominator comment: “As a freshman, Michael appeared as an intelligent, friendly and quirky kid. The more I got to know him ,the more I learned of his passion, empathy and high motivation. Michael is a natural role model and leader among peers and adults, alike.” - Kathleen DeLuca, school counselor.

search_result.text:
WIL

Schools are encourged to submit photographs to be posted online with High School Report and also in the print version of Crossroads when space allows. A submitted photograph should be a high resolution jpg and include a caption with people identified. Email to stringers@delawareonline.com.

Brandywine

Brandywine

Another Spirit Week starts Monday. Monday is Pajama Day, Tuesday Twin Day, Wednesday Tie Dye Day, Feb. 13 BHS Spirit Day, Feb. 14 Class Colors Day. Hallway decorating will take place Feb. 13 after school; all students should contact class officers on how to help.

The Class of 2014 is collaborating with Aeropostale and DoSomething.org in a service project called Jeans For Teens. The effort, lead by senior Joel Hurtt, addresses the fact that one in three people who are homeless are younger than 18 years old, and jeans are the most requested item by them. Any old or unworn jeans should be brought to the school by Feb. 14 and placed in the designated box located in the main office. The goal is 1,000 jeans.

Emily Hyde

Concord

Midterms concluded starting the first week of the second semester last week. Students began to adjust to new schedules and meet new teachers. The first-semester report-card grades and midterms were distributed last week. The first semester grades also were sent to the colleges the seniors applied to automatically by the school.

A Confident Parenting workshop was held at Claymont Elementary School. This seminar was to help struggling parents to become more adjusted into their roles.

The annual Polar Bear Plunge was held Sunday at Rehoboth Beach to raise funds for the Special Olympics Delaware. For the third year in a row, the Concord Cannonballs participated. The team was led by seniors Rhiannon Downey and Alex Gendrachi, under the supervision of the Blue-Gold adviser Donna Ames.

Wednesday, a police presentation on senior week was offered to parents and students. The police answered questions and left the students and parents more informed of the rules and regulations concerning those participants of beach week.

Mount Pleasant

The Michael C. Ferguson Achievement Awards, granted to those few students receiving the most outstanding scores in DCAS testing, were given to eight Mount Pleasant students for their exceptional performance last year as sophomores. They included: Emma Chambless, Lydia Christman, Alexis Ellison, John Kee, Kali Panella, Jordan Siskin, David Unterberger and Rebecca Williams.

Blue-Gold senior ambassadors Molly Kerrigan and Annie Garner and junior ambassadors Abby Betts and Melinda Bilous attended a leadership training session for the Blue-Gold Game on June 21.

Another winter concert will be held on the evening of Feb. 18.

The Prom Fashion Show will be held Feb. 28 in the auditorium.

The annual musical has been announced and casted; director Chris Turner and the school will present "Hairspray" on March 27, 28 and 29.

The National Honor Society soon will begin its "Pennies for Patients" fundraiser for leukemia, and the period A class collecting the most change will be served a complimentary breakfast.

Sydney Nye

Colonial

William Penn

The Young Playwrights hosts a competition in which students can submit their own original five to 10 page plays and have them published and performed. The Delaware division of the program is sponsored by the Delaware Theater Company. This year's competition started in September; winning plays will be performed in March. Student Samantha Stewart's play "To Break the Ice" was one of the four selected from the Delaware to be performed. "I've always loved to write and act, so I really enjoyed this," said Samantha.

This year's theme was "A small detail making a big difference."

"I got the idea for my play from a pick-up line I heard," said Samantha. "It was, 'how much does a polar bear weigh? Enough to break the ice' ... I got the idea for the main character to use it and begin talking to the other main character, and that's where it starts."

The Delaware Theatre Company will present the winning plays later this year.

More information is available on The Delaware Theatre Company website.

Jessica Paoletti

and Aeon Scott

Red Clay

Alexis I. du Pont

Tami Soltow, science and legal processes teacher, recently was selected to receive the 2014 Award for Excellence as a Classroom LRE Teacher by the Delaware Law Related Education Center.

The school will hold an open house at the Latin American Community Center on from 6 to 7 p.m. Feb. 18. Uniforms will be on display along with information about various programs.

The Nature and Garden Club has received various "plaque level" donations toward its "Walkway to Success" brick fund. Sponsors so far include the "Hoe 'n Hope Garden Club," which has donated more than $1,000, former A.I. chemistry teacher Barb Borleski and former A.I. biology teacher Eddie McGrath.

Austin Griffith

Charter

Student Hannah Cho has been named concertmaster of the Delaware Honors Orchestra Festival, the new Delaware All-State Orchestra. She was also ranked No. 1 in the top 10 overall scores.

Freshman Caden Anderson recently completed his Eagle Scout project. He and fellow students Eamon and Patrick O'Conner, Spencer Harmon, Michael Lan and other local musicians provided a concert for families at the Ronald McDonald House. In addition, he also collected more than 100 pounds of food, cleaning supplies and new toys for the house.

Monica Keszler has been awarded with the 2014 Scholastics Gold Key Portfolio Award for her senior portfolio. She is the only one from Charter this year to receive the award, and one of two from the Cab Calloway AP Studio Art class. Her work in full, all eight submitted pieces, will be on display at Delaware State University in Dover on Feb. 8. Other Scholastics Art Awards from Charter include Individual Gold Key and Silver Key Portfolio winner Christine Fu, Individual Silver Key winners Seoyeon Kim, Julia Lin and Ginda Sun and Honorable Mention Portfolio Isabelle Elkins. All Gold Key works will be submitted for national adjudication later this year.

Ben Fickles, Asher Feldman and Hannah Beiner were recipients of the 2014 Scholastic Writing Award. C

The HUG Club has started its Second Annual Prom Dress Drop collection. All donated dresses will be sold for $10 and all proceeds will be donated to IFOPA, an organization dedicated to researching for the cure for Fibrodysplasia ossificans progressiva, a rare muscle disease in which damaged connective tissue fails to grow.

Following in the spirit of giving back, the Bollywood Dance Club recently held a World's Fair dance show at Brandywine Springs Elementary School. Dance groups performed dances from countries around the world, and varying cuisine from foreign nations was provided. All proceeds went to Kolkata Sanved, a charity which removes children from human trafficking circles, and instead teaches them dance as a form of therapy.

Tobias Mazal

Conrad

The state Department of Education is running a fundraiser for HOSA Future Health Professionals. The money raised is to help fund National Conference travel for the five students who are state officers. JulietteEmery is one of them. Please consider purchasing some jewelry from the online catalog.

About 1,000 plus interviews of potential students have been conduced by the school so far this year. Choice applications closed Jan. 8. Almost 1,500 students applied this year.

TravisTesta was chosen as Conrad's player representative for the Blue-Gold All-Star football game in June. LizGraham will represent Conrad on the Blue Team cheerleading squad.

Freshman Katrina Hardy placed second in Delaware in the Disability History and Awareness Month Poster Contest from the Governor's Advisory Council for Exceptional Citizens. Katrina represented Conrad at an awards luncheon in Dover with Lt. Gov. MattDenn.

David and BryceFender have earned Eagle Scout rank, the highest in Boy Scouting. David is a recent graduate and Bryce is a junior. Both young men have earned six other previous ranks having to do with aspects of camping, life, cooking and survival skills. Only two out of 100 people who join the Boy Scouts achieve this level.

Alexia Scott

Delaware Military

The start of the third marking period began Monday. If the first two haven't gone as planned, now is the time to make the necessary changes.

Letters of acceptance have been sent to the incoming 2014-15 freshman class. We are looking forward to having these young men and women become part of the DMA family.

Monday was Community Service Day. Many cadets and staff attended the Polor Bear Plunge in Rehoboth Beach on Sunday.

The wrestling team went 2-1 in a quad meet two weekends ago. They defeated Caravel and Lake Forest. The boys varsity and JV basketball teams defeated McKean two weeks ago, as well. The varsity boys team improved to 8-4 on the season. The girls basketball team also defeated McKean to improve to 7-4 on the season. The boys swim team defeated both Archmere and Sanford. The girls swim team got its first win of the season against Sanford, as well.

Brittany Carson

Dickinson

Jobs for Delaware Graduates held its officer induction ceremony on Jan. 21. The ceremony, conducted by adviser Dionie Lum, recognized Randi Hocker (president), Terri Harden (vice-president), Daniel DiPilla (secretary), Xavier Deleon (treasurer), Jaylon Dickerson (co-historian) and Carlshay Williams (co-historian).

Junior Seth Schilling was published in the January issue of Teen Ink magazine. Schilling wrote a poem, "Masque."

The February Dickinson Support Association meeting will take place at 7 p.m. Tuesday in the library.

The February Coffee Series will take place from 8 to 9 a.m. Wednesday. Interested parents of prospective students can see the school during a typical day. Contact the main office at 992-5500, ext. 301, to reserve a spot. Coffee will be served.

McKean

Do you, your relatives, or friends have have a 3- to 4-year-old child who is ready for more than your mom's playgroup? If you do, please consider enrolling them in the McKean's Lil Highlanders, a four-day play group styled preschool designed to provide children with activities to promote social and educational development. The morning session runs from 9:15 to 10:45 Mondays through Thursdays. Cost is $50 a month.

The staff is McKean high school students who have demonstrated excellence. They will be supervised by a qualified early childhood educator. For more information, contact director Lisa Gonzon at 992-1949

Today's theme on The WMHS music party will be "Forgive and Forget." at 2:30 p.m. on WMHS-FM (88.1).

Moises Velazquez

Charter

Newark Charter

On Jan. 28, ninth-graders from the global studies class traveled to Washington with teacher Lisa Westerfield for a seminar organized by the Genocide Awareness Organization from the Enough Project. They included Megan McCormick, Selena Juarez, Elaine Ansah, Paige Feldman, Aashna Kohtari, Luci Ostheimer, Patrick Carmen, Brianna Johnson, Annie Greene and Cece Moore. They discussed Sudan and what they can do to help the schools in Darfur refugee camps, including receiving a Darfuri sister school. They also went to the House of Representatives to seek support for a bill allowing the United States to send aid to the refugees in Darfur.

In other news, the Mock Trial team is preparing for its competition Feb. 21-22 at the New Castle County Courthouse.

The eighth-grade Math League Team placed first and second in the Jan. 28 Regional Competition. The team was led by top scorers Michael Chen and Christina Kim.

The seventh-grade Math League Team won first, second and third place in the Regional Competition. Joannie Wang and Mathias Heider led the school with top scores. After three meets, Joannie currently leads all seventh-graders in the region.

Luci Ostheimer

Private

Archmere

An app imagined by a team of Archmere students won "Best in State" in the Verizon Innovative App Challenge. Led by computer science teacher Jared Campbell, students Christian Kraft, Gregory McCord, Joseph Spall, Andrew Hurst and Nicholas McIntyre developed the concept for a mobile application they call "coNextGen," which helps individuals locate family members and friends in the event of a natural disaster. This past November, Campbell presented the Verizon Innovative App Challenge to the students, all of whom had excelled in computer science courses at Archmere, such as a class taught by Campbell called "App Development," and encouraged them to enter. A stipulation of the challenge is that students must develop "an original mobile app concept that incorporates STEM and addresses a need or problem in their school or community."

The team is now eligible for Best in Region Honors, which would earn them a $5,000 grant for the school and virtual coding training from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Lab development experts. If they win, they also would advance to the national-level competition, which brings a $15,000 grant and tablet computers. Winning the national-level competition would mean seeing coNextGen come to life. Verizon plans to release the results of the regional-level competition this February.

Jan. 20 was Catholic Schools Week and Bishop Malooly celebrated Mass with students and later in the week, the students closed a spirited week with cake along with an assembly. Students held a bake sale to raise money for Blue-Gold and the Special Olympics. Students also bought T-shirts with the proceeds also supporting Blue Gold. Students wore these shirts to Thursday's basketball game against St. Mark's.

Kendall Aulen

Caravel

Junior Brooke Dawson's debut single, "The Right Way," recently placed second in an Australian songwriter contest and was eligible for the 2013 "Homey Award" on WSTW. Brooke also recently aired on national television on an episode of "The Haunting Of."

Juniors Victoria Edwards and Olivia Kwiatkowski have works that will be featured in the 2013 Excellence in Drawing for the Delaware Foundation for the Visual Arts Calendar.

Fairwinds Christian

Last week, students participated in the annual Spirit Week. Each day was based off a game. For example; Monday was the game of Life. On that day, the students came dressed as lawyers, nurses, chefs and other occupations. The Candyland themed Tuesday had all the students arriving to school dressed as candy canes, Skittles, M&Ms, mints and other candy. On Wednesday was the game Battleship with students dressed as the men and women that serve the country or as police officers, firemen and others who help protect our nation. Thursday was school color day so students were dressed in green, gold and white accesories and clothes. Lastly, fancy Friday encouraged all students to come in nice appropriate dress clothes.

Many basketball games have been played. On Jan. 24 there were away games against Milford and on Jan. 28th home games against Fairton. There were also junior varsity and varisty boy and girl basketball home games against the Falcons and Chestertown on Jan. 31. On Tuesday there was home games against Calvary. There are home games today, also against Calvary.

People can follow the school on Instagram @FCSKnights and like the Facebook page, Fairwinds Christian School.

Kara Gallaher

Padua

During last week's Catholic Schools Week/Spirit Week, Padua celebrated its four pillars: Spirituality, Scholarship, Service and Sisterhood. Monday was Spirituality Day, with a schoolwide scavenger hunt hosted by Campus Ministry. Tuesday was Scholarship Day, focusing on Community Homeroom and awards. Wednesday was Sisterhood Day, in which pairs or groups of friends dressed as twins. Thursday was Service Day and Teacher Appreciation Day. Friday was Spirit Day, with an afternoon Spirit Assembly and dress-down. In addition, Student Council raffled off an iPad mini, Padua gear, and gift cards for iTunes and Bath and Body Works.

The Polar Bear Plunge is a significant fundraiser for Special Olympics Delaware, an organization that supports people with cognitive disabilities. Padua has supported the initiatives of Special Olympics and Project Unify through its Project Unify and Blue Gold Clubs. Padua organized a Padua Plunge team to participate in Sunday's event.

The College Essay Writing Seminar began last week for all juniors. The College 101 course will begin Feb. 10. The course, offered by the Office of College Advisement, is designed to teach the juniors about the college process.

Students are in the process of selecting courses for the 2014-15 academic year. The Freshmen Scheduling Night was held Wednesday. Students and parents were provided with information in assisting with the course selection process. Freshmen, sophomores and their parents are encouraged to schedule college advisement meetings to discuss the courses they are projected to take.

All students enrolled in one or more advanced placement courses have received information regarding exam registration forms. Students with any questions should contact Mary McClory.

French Week will be Feb. 24-28. An artist from Kennett Design will visit 2 to 4 p.m. Feb. 26. Students can learn how to create a version of Van Gogh's "Starry Night." The afternoon also includes house-made crepes by French teachers Megan Boyle and Susan Burris.

Teachers Mike Sheehan and Chris Wills have been selected to present Padua's Advocacy Program for Success at the Canadian Positive Psychology Conference in Ottawa, Ontario, in July. They will discuss their experiences in developing the seven qualities of success and how these qualities improve academic performance and social interactions.

In collaboration with professor Keith Weigelt of University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business, Padua will offer a one-week entrepreneurship program this summer for interested students. Working closely with Team Business, Weigelt has created Entrepreneur in the Classroom, a program that teaches business literacy. Topics that will be covered include: business plan Ideas, competitive environments, sales and marketing, pricing strategies, operations, human resources, management and accounting. Students will collaborate in teams and develop skills through hands-on exercises. The class is scheduled for the week of July 7. Parents whose daughters are interested in participating should contact head of school Cindy Mann as soon as possible.

Nikki Rash

Salesianum

Snowy weather couldn't damper spirits during a fun Feast Week in honor of patron saint Francis de Sales. On Jan. 20, many students chose to spend the Martin Luther King Jr. Day holiday volunteering in the Wilmington and Philadelphia areas. On Jan. 21, students attended a Martin Luther King Jr. Day prayer service before the snow sent everyone home early. Jan. 22 was a snow day, canceling plans for a school trivia game.

The Feast Day of Francis de Sales was celebrated with a school Mass on Jan. 23. All seniors were given medals with St. Francis' image, to remind them that they carry his teachings with them wherever they go.

The week ended Jan. 24 with a high-energy pep rally honoring winter sports. A student-faculty basketball game and foul shooting contest were some of the highlights, and some alumni participated.

Sanford

"Annie" premieres at 6:30 tonight and features students from the lower, middle and upper schools. The show runs 7:30 p.m. Friday and Saturday and 2 p.m. Sunday. Tickets are $12 at the door.

Senior basketball player Alison Lewis exceeded the 1,000-point milestone during the The Warriors' success at the Boardwalk Classic in Wildwood, N.J. Lewis was honored at Sanford during a conference game last month. She will play basketball for Boston University Women's Basketball program next year on a full scholarship.

Several upper school students will perform in Delaware All-State Theatre's production of "The Drowsy Chaperone." Junior Jordan McMillan will play the title role. Senior Christopher Malafronti will playFeldzieg. Seniors Emily Malafronti and Emma Heberton and junior Kate Holden were selected for the ensemble. Clint Williams, Sanford Performing Arts chairman, will be the music director for the show. The performances will be at Tatnall on June 20-22 and 27-29.

Correction: Freshman Katie Curran earned a Silver Key in the Scholastic Arts competition for her digital art piece "Comic Lips."

Middle School Spelling Bee champion Lilly Allingham will participate in the State Spelling Bee at St. Mark's High School on March 1.

The Service Club held its annual Spaghetti Dinner in Quigley Dining Hall Jan 24. Students and their families enjoyed food served by Service Club members while watching musical performances by students. Proceeds from the dinner will go to Habitat for Humanity, Emily Bissell Hospital and other supported charities.

Brooke Finnicum

St. Elizabeth

As part of Catholic Schools Week, St. Elizabeth welcomed nearly 400 students from Diocesan middle schools and entertained them with a mini variety show. St. E ambassadors were taken to their middle school alma maters to ride buses back to St. E with the visitors.

Artwork by art instructor Jen Mrozek will be on display at the Redding Gallery of the City/County Building in Wilmington this month. An opening reception for the exhibition "Words of Love" is scheduled from 5:30 to 8 p.m. Friday.

The Corbi Drive ends Friday. School families and staff are asked to have their orders submitted by the end of the school day.

Anatomy classes will take a field trip on Friday to the Mutter Museum of the College of Physicians of Philadelphia. America's finest museum of medical history, the Mütter displays its collections of anatomical specimens, models, and medical instruments in a 19th-century "cabinet museum" setting. The goal of the museum is to help the public understand the mysteries and beauty of the human body while appreciating the history of diagnosis and treatment of disease.

An assembly will be held Monday at which the March 6 blood drive will be discussed.

Freshmen will select their courses for the next academic year on Monday.

"Breaking Glass," a play written by freshman Nikolas Hunter, has been chosen as one of the six finalist plays in the 2013-2014 Delaware Young Playwrights Festival sponsored by the Delaware Theatre Company. Finalists will participate in a series of playwriting workshops with professional theater artists from DTC to further refine their writing and ready their works for a public showcase performance on March 11 on the DTC stage.

St. Elizabeth High has offered academic scholarships to 34 students from area middle schools: Alfred G. Waters Middle School: Matthew Gray, Emily Gray; All Saints Catholic School: Brandon Dongfack, Danielle Eckton; Christ the Teacher Catholic School: Lorenzo Alafriz, Matthew Balbierer, Colby Corrozi, Isabel Durnan, Owen Fink, Joel Hafycz, Nicole Kirk, Rebecca Miller, Corey O'Donnell; H.B. duPont Middle School: Sarah Kunkle; Holy Angels School: Nicholas Kayatta; Immaculate Heart of Mary School: Francis Doran, Matthew Hurst, Brendan Wilhelm; P.S. duPont Middle School: Sarayu Sivaram; St. Edmond's Academy: Dylan Kirk; St. Elizabeth Middle School: Alena Boyer, Rebecca Gonzalez, Irene Hu, Emily Marvel, Abigail Thompson, Evelyn Welsh; St. John the Beloved School: Ava Stratton; St. Mary Magdalen: Karl Bryan, Liam Lehane; St. Peter the Apostle School: Reiley Bond; The Independence School: Adair Bartram, Eric Ziegler; Northley Middle School (Pa.): Rebecca Gomes; and St. Philomena Academy (Pa.): Elizabeth Brutsche.

Vincent DiLissio

St. Mark's

Call at least one week in advance to make a reservation for a Spartan for a Day visit Call Shustine Brooks in the admissions office at 757-8721.

The Parent Association's fourth annual Wine and Beer Tasting is from 7 to 10 p.m. Feb. 22 in the cafeteria.Cost is $10 in advance and $15 at the door. Tickets may be purchased online and through the main office. A few will be available at the door. For questions, contact Francis Corrigan at fcorrigan@stmarkshs.net.

The Spartan Athletic Club Concert and Auction will be held March 29. Listen to the sounds of Blue Label, led by former Burnt Sienna frontman Jefe. Contact S.A.C. committee members Brian Murray at btmurray@btmurray.net or Michele Mirabella at mirabella22@verizon.net, for information.

Freshman Sarah Eissmann and Lucie Melvin are recipients of the just-announced 2013 Michael C. Ferguson scholarship, which is based on high achievement on the Delaware Comprehensive Assessment System test taken in the eighth-grade. Eismann was a student at Newark Charter School and Melvin was a student at Shue-Medill Middle School. Both girls received the award for their outstanding reading scores.

On Jan. 11 freshman Madison Sycalik was recognized by the Delaware Pony Club, a local United States Pony Clubs chapter, for her achievements, volunteerism and perseverance in the face of adversity with its annual Lanzi Award. Sycalik has been a member of the DPC since age 6 and has represented the Delmarva Region at national championships three times in the past four years. She hopes to qualify and competing again for eventing in July 2014 in Lexington, Ky. Sycalik was named captain at last year's championships, despite being the youngest member of the team.

This past weekend, senior officers of the Student Council presented at the National Association of Secondary School Principals LEAD Conference in Washington. The LEAD Conferences offer experiential leadership skills development to students and advisers in student government, National Honor Society and National Junior Honor Society. Presenters included Executive President Luke Duchemin, Executive Treasurer David Alessandrini, Senior Vice President Matthew Sutton and Senior Treasurer Sarah Dombroski. Other students who attended include Kathryn Fish, Trevor Boulden, Jeffrey Pala, James Hamory, Matthew DiPietro, Allan Carlsen, Spencer Jones, Elizabeth Danberg and Chelsea Vincelette.

The annual Shakespeare Competition will be held at 10 a.m. Saturday. Questions should be directed to Anne Eanes.

Parent College Information Night will be held in the cafeteria from 7 to 9 p.m. Important details of the college application process will be discussed. This night is geared for juniors and their parents but underclassmen and their parents are welcome to attend. Contact Wayne Smeigh or Yvette Drazich in college placement for more information.

Registration for the class of 2018 was held Jan. 20. For information on registering, contact Matthew Evans, director of admissions, at 757-8723.

Jake Bertelson

Tatnall

On Jan. 28, the Board of Trustees and the Search Committee announced the appointment of Charles A. Tierney III as the school's ninth Head of School, to succeed Eric G. Ruoss effective July 1. Committee and board members reached a unanimous decision to appoint Tierney, citing his experience, passion for education and strong character.

Tierney joins Tatnall from Northfield Mount Hermon in Mount Hermon, Mass., where he is the assistant head of school. During his 16-year tenure, he has been responsible for curriculum development, fundraising initiatives, faculty oversight and management of a STEM-building task force. In addition, he recently served as Interim Head of School, with responsibility for the day-to-day operations of the school, including managing its $30 million annual operating budget and overseeing its $3.4 million annual fund.

Prior to working at NMH, he was director of studies at St. Stephen's School in Rome from 1996-98. He earned a bachelor's degree in history from Dartmouth College in 1985 and a master's in education from Columbia University as a Klingenstein Fellow in 1994.

The Political Action Club hosted Delaware Gov. Jack Markell Jan. 24. Over the past several months, the club has hosted several guest speakers as part of their "Speaking Truth into Politics" series to help increase knowledge about local, state and national government. Markell addressed how he became involved in politics and the role students play in civic engagement.

The School Coffee House is at 7 p.m. Friday at World Café Live at The Queen. Students, faculty and alumni will perform.

Tower Hill

The art exhibition "Threshold" opens on Friday in the Founders' Gallery. Hours are 6 to 8 p.m. and it will feature found-art sculptures and crafted paintings by Phillipa Beardsley and Mark Blavat. The show will remain on display through February.

The Jefferson Awards winners for November and December were Rachel Minkovitz and Taylor Reese. Minkovitz worked with two organizations, the St. Michael's school and nursery and at the Delaware Art Museum's summer art camp. In her 61 hours of service with St. Michael's, she worked with kindergarten, first- and second-graders in arts and crafts. At the art museum, she oversaw projects and monitored campers. Reese has given 92 hours to the Special Olympics, an organization she has worked with for the last seven years. She has facilitated, organized and scheduled matches for special olympics athletes and works diligently in all the tasks asked of her.

Zach Nitsche is the January Jefferson Awards winner as well as a DuPont Service Awards winner. Nitsche has given more than 100 hours to the first tee organization, which teaches young children golf. In addition, he has helped organize many events in the Tower Hill community such as the Blue-Gold fashion show and the dodgeball tournament. This along with Nitsche's "outstanding character and commitment to service" is why he also was awarded for the DuPont Service Award.

Junior Kalee Kennedy, senior Vanna Ramirez and junior Taylor Reese have been awarded Scholastic Writing awards. Kennedy's flash fiction story, "I am and I Love" won a gold key award and her flash fiction, "Whispers (Schizo)" won honorable mention. Wilmington Friends

On Jan. 23 upper school students, faculty, and guest speakers led workshops related to the work of Martin Luther King Jr. The "teach-in" was designed to involve every student and faculty member in an afternoon of workshops on themes of social justice.

Events included parent David Wakeley, who led a Quaker Life Committee workshop about John Woolman, an 18th-century Quaker from New Jersey who was one of the earliest abolitionists and led efforts to make peaceful contacts with American Indians. The African-American Affinity Club led an interactive workshop called "What's Race have to do with it?" using activities from this year's National Association of Independent Schools Student Diversity Leadership Conference. The Equality Now Club introduced and led a discussion following a "salon screening" of the PBS film based on the book by the same name, "Half the Sky: Turning Oppression into Opportunity for Women Worldwide." The "Before I Die" Mural Committee's program focused on both the meaning and significance of community art and the idea of bucket lists and setting goals for the common good. A faculty group led a session, with live performances, on the evolution of music that addresses themes of social justice. Editors of the student newspaper led a discussion on the role of journalism in fostering social change. The Peace and Ecology Club hosted University of Delaware professor Chrysanthi Leon, who talked about lobbying and specifically the work and mission of the Friends Committee on National Legislation. The Gay Straight Alliance workshop involved a simulation of the process of "coming out" for those who have not had the experience, including the responses that are more and less likely from different groups. Amnesty International developed a board game to simulate the real-life struggle of Syrian refugees. Students who have been on recent trips to Haiti and Africa related their experiences to King's mission. Guest speakers involved with urban youth programs combining athletics and tutoring talked about how sports and academics can be complementary in efforts to assist at-risk students. Other student-led programs included a think tank for creative expression of global problems and a workshop about how "water changes everything," including equality in health, education and economic opportunity.

The 17th annual Quaker Youth Leadership Conference, with students from schools around the world, begins today at Westtown (Pa.) School. Westtown and Delaware Valley Friends are hosting this year's conference, with the theme "SPICEing up the 21st Century: Integrity." The Conference will include workshops, service projects, affinity groups, Meeting for Worship and reflection to help build leadership skills and address important issues of integrity. Wilmington Friends will be represented at the conference by seniors Elena Veale and Laura Gates, junior Steven Ly, sophomores Jack Bulk and Ty Moyer and freshman Evelyn Wakeley. The faculty chaperon will be Ellen Johnson, upper school Science teacher.

Friday, Head of Middle School Jonathan Huxtable will host a coffee for sixth-grade parents, and students in the middle school Chinese program will lead a celebration of Chinese New Year in the afternoon.

Friends parents will provide lunch for Emmanuel Dining Room Jackson Street on Saturday, and the faculty and staff will serve lunch at EDR Walnut Street on Tuesday.

On Tuesday, the Quaker Closet quality re-sale shop will be open to the public, 8:15 a.m. to 4 p.m.

Kenji Endo

Staff Report

@MyCentralJersey

May is International Rotary Youth Service Month and the Clinton Sunrise Rotary Club celebrated the month with two different honors to students who excel.

A $3,000 scholarship was awarded to North Hunterdon Polytech Senior Erin Shaw. Her parents Robert and Maureen Shaw, and Polytech Coordinator of Student Services Tanya Nalesnik presided.

"As usual, the selection process, which is based on numerous factors, was difficult with many exceptional candidates from Polytech. However, Erin Shaw stood out above the rest with her extracurricular activities and especially her community service”, said Kevin Gillman, youth coordinator for the club. “Service to the community is a key principle for Rotarians.”

Along with Kevin, Rotary President MaryBeth Sullivan, also presented the First Annual Leadership award to North Hunterdon seniors Jessica Mitchell and Kyle Hensler. This award goes to seniors who display outstanding leadership qualities and are members of the North Hunterdon Interact Club. The Interact Club is a Rotary International sponsored High School Club with ideals that follow the same Avenues of Service that Rotarians follow. The Clinton Sunrise and North Hunterdon Rotary clubs co-sponsors Interact at North Hunterdon High School with both Anthony Petraglia and Dina Marron as the school’s Interact Facilitator’s.

“We are so pleased that we are able to support the next generation of Leaders with our new program," Rotary President Mary Beth Sullivan said.

The Clinton Sunrise club also mentors students through a longstanding program at Polytech called Bridging the Gap under the guidance of Commercial Art Teacher Teresa Diaz. The program is under way currently and will end this month with an awards ceremony at Polytech’s Career’s Cafe on Central’s campus.

For more about the club and its activities, visit www.clintonsunriserotary.org or contact Rotary at 908-279-0112. Meetings are at 7:30 a.m. Thursdays at the Clinton Fire House on New Street in the Town of Clinton.

Bound Brook American Legion Post 63

Giles Biondi American Legion Post 63 of Bound Brook has awarded their 2018 annual college scholarships to Bound Brook High School seniors Houston Ward and Eduardo Vargas Gutierrez.

Scholarship Committee Chairman Tom Synnott along with committee members; Post 63 Commander Robert Newell, Chairman of the Board of Trustees and Post Financial Officer Ben Auletta and Legion member Lee Politica selected the two students.

Houston Ward, who was previously selected by Post 63 to attend the 2017 New Jersey Boys State, has two grandfathers, an uncle and father who served in the U.S. military. In the fall, he will attend the University of Delaware and intends to seek a career in medicine. Along with his high academic achievements, he currently ranks number eight in his 119-member high school class. Ward has participated in numerous co-curricular community service and work experiences.

Eduardo Vargas Gutierrez immigrated to the U.S. from Costa Rica in 2012, and is anticipating earning his U.S. citizenship. Along with his many co-curricular activities including membership in the extremely successful Bound Brook High School Robotics Team, he also has extensive contributions in voluntary and community service activities together with multiple job experiences.

Choosing two candidates out of the field of highly qualified students presented to the committee by BBHS Guidance Department Secretary Kathleen Jordan, proved to be extremely difficult. “Their levels of scholastic achievement along with strong records of school activities and community service make us extremely proud of the quality of the children graduating in Bound Brook,” Trustee Chair, Auletta said.

All veterans of honorable service during a wartime period, and those currently serving on active duty, are eligible to belong to The American Legion. Congress chartered The American Legion in 1919 as a veteran’s service organization and the organization is soon to reach its 100th birthday. Since its founding, The American Legion has remained focused on activities that serve veterans and their families, youth, their local communities, state, and nation.
