search_result.title: Chesapeake blue crab rebound 'a success story'
search_result.text:
Jeremy Cox

jcox6@delmarvanow.com

Fisherman Scott Wivell's license allows him to sprinkle up to 255 crab pots around Virginia's portion of the Chesapeake Bay.

Last Monday, he only had to check 220 to reach his daily limit of bushels.

"Crabs," he said, "are everywhere."

Up and down the bay, watermen are returning to shore with hulls brimming with blue crabs. To be sure, it's a good season for the Chesapeake icon. But it also represents a lucrative payoff after eight years of grudging sacrifice.

Since 2008, Maryland and Virginia have put themselves on a strict diet, lowering the limit on the number of female crabs that could be harvested and ending the winter dredge fishery, among other actions.

For the first time since that watershed year, the Virginia Marine Resources Commission, which manages the commonwealth's crab fishery, is considering loosening some restrictions, such as reopening winter dredging. The Maryland Department of Natural Resources isn't there yet, but it may be open to making some mid-year changes that would allow more crabs to be harvested, officials say.

The regulations, painful as they have been, are a big reason that Wivell and other watermen are so busy now, scientists say.

The bay-wide crab population, according to last winter's survey, is estimated at 553 million, almost double the total abundance from 2008. While the 194 million females is slightly below the 215 million target, it does come in above the minimum threshold of 70 million.

“To me, this is a real success story," said Rom Lipcius, a professor at the Virginia Institute of Marine Science. "What was implemented in 2008 is truly effective fishery management.”

Staving off disaster

Lipcius contrasts the plight of the blue crab with the rockfish, also known as the striped bass. Its stocks were so depleted that Maryland imposed an all-out ban on catching the fish in 1985 and didn't lift it until the population had recovered — nearly six years later.

“I’m familiar with a lot of fishery failures," Lipcius said.

For years, crabs seemed relatively immune to the stressors in the bay that had decimated rockfish and oysters. But by 2008, their abundance had fallen to less than one-third of 1993 levels.

CONTEXT: This year's winter dredge survey revealed further gains in Chesapeake crabs.

In a historic action, three jurisdictions — Maryland, Virginia and the Potomac River Fisheries Commission — acted to save one of the bay's most-prized species.

“It was really needed in terms of crab management in Chesapeake Bay," said Chris Moore, senior Virginia scientist for the Chesapeake Bay Foundation.

The crab population hasn't grown steadily — harsh winters and an eating spree on juveniles by red drum and other predators fueled severe dips in 2013 and 2014 — but the general trend has been an upswing.

Scientists credit this year's mild winter, in part, with the current resurgence. If it had been as cold as it was last year, the population increase would have been cut in half, said Brenda Davis, Maryland's blue crab program manager.

Crucially, after years of harvesting females above the sustainable threshold of 34 percent of the entire stock, watermen have been consistently staying at or below the bay-wide goal of 25 percent, she said.

OPINION: Why the winter crab survey is so crucial.

The new regulations left the seafood industry with fewer crabs — and fewer dollars — to go around. Wivell, for one, saw his daily bushel limit slashed from 51 to 29. Assuming a modest dock price of $25 per bushel, that was $550 a day no longer going into his pocket.

Worse, in an effort to reduce the overall catch of females by up to 40 percent, officials shut down the winter dredge. That protected females from being scooped up from their muddy burrows, but it marked an end to the year-round fishery. As a result, several processing plants in the region shut their doors.

"That, in essence, killed our industry," Wivell said.

Tangier Island used to have one of the most bustling dredging fleets along with the York River, said Daniel Dise, a waterman who lives on the island. Many have switched to oysters, putting more pressure on that fragile fishery.

Population strong

Some relief may be on the way.

Virginia's crab managers are considering moving up the opening date of the crab pot season from March 17 to March 1, Lipcius said. Global warming trends appear to be heating up the bay earlier, putting crabs on the move. A change in the calendar would almost certainly be offset by a reduction in bushel limits, he added.

Year after year, the Marine Resources Commission had declined to reopen the winter dredge, but 2017 may put an end to that streak, Lipcius said. Maybe.

“We’re at a time at which the population is strong, when management has provided a buffer to manage disturbances. We need to be cautiously optimistic," he said. But "you don’t want to make drastic changes at this point.”

Another move in the works: possibly extending the peeler season from Sept. 25 to Oct. 31, which would be a particular boon to Tangier-area crabbers.

Some tweaks are possible to this season in Maryland, Davis said. When abundance is up, the harvest can be raised without threatening proportion-based targets. The state Blue Crab Industry Advisory Committee is expected to discuss possible changes soon. The changes, if any are made, would go into effect by July 1.

Whatever happens, managers should proceed with caution, said Moore of the Bay Foundation.

“We’re still not at the target for female abundance yet. A few tweaks are what we’ve done as they population has moved up and down. We don’t have a survey that gives us information that allows us to make big wholesale changes in the fishery," he said.

TIDES: The spectacular life cycle of a crab

Contact reporter Jeremy Cox at 410-845-4630 or on Twitter @Jeremy_Cox.

search_result.title: OC fishermen build reefs for new fisheries, blue water
search_result.text:
Gino Fanelli

gfanelli@dmg.gannett.com

On a frigid winter morning, the Morning Star, piloted by Capt. Monty Hawkins, moves east from the Ocean City Fishing Center.

Its cargo is a modest group of volunteers, a couple bags of Royal Farms fried chicken and six and a half tons of cement blocks.

Hawkins, of the nonprofit Ocean City Reef Foundation, and his crew are dedicated to rebuilding the reefs off the coast of Ocean City, dropping off tons of cement blocks that plant the seeds for healthy fish populations. Formerly abundant with vibrant fisheries, oyster reefs and, further off the shore, corals, the coastal reefs were decimated by large scale trawling in the mid-20th century.

"This kind of rock that builds these reefs, you can pick it up and crush it in your hand," Hawkins said. "It's so fragile, and what they would do is drag these massive pieces of machinery across the bottom, which would destroy these reefs."

Since the passage of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery and Conservation Act in 1976, and ensuing revisions through the 1990s which further regulated trawl fishing in federal waters, overfishing in the mid-Atlantic has been significantly reduced. According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's 2015 report on fishing stocks, only two mid-Atlantic stocks are subjects of overfishing: summer flounder and yellowtail flounder.

Despite strides in regulating fishing, Hawkins said the devastation to the habitats is already done, making the work of the Ocean City fisherman and other environmental groups even more important to ocean protection as new threats arise.

Researchers say climate change continues to endanger the ocean's health, and as President Donald Trump has taken office, his executive orders have threatened previous administration's protection orders that could lead to oil drilling and other actions previously considered dangerous to the environment.

"Back in the 1960s, you'd hear about people catching white marlin seven or eight miles off the coast," Hawkins said. "Now, it's 30 or 40 miles, and that's because these fisheries have just been ruined."

Hawkins' work, bringing out either large hauls of cement in one go or dropping a few blocks during routine fishing, aims to bring back these fisheries by promoting the resurgence of crucial marine life habitats — oyster reefs being a major component.

The importance of oysters

Oysters play a crucial part in the fragile oceanic ecosystem, one which Hawkins said is invaluable in keeping the ocean water clean.

"If you look at the ocean now, the water is green," Hawkins said. "Sometimes it gets so bad that it almost looks like paste. That's phytoplankton."

Phytoplankton are microscopic, single-celled plants that serve as the basis for the oceanic food chain. While crucial to the overall survival of marine life and the primary diet for oysters, left to grow unchecked, phytoplankton pose a threat of algal blooms.

"When you have a lot of algae, what that can lead to is low dissolved oxygen levels, which are harmful to marine life," said Bo Lusk, a coastal scientist with the Nature Conservancy in Virginia.

The death and subsequent decay of the phytoplankton effectively drains the habitat of oxygen, leading to large scale marine deaths known as fish kills. An algal bloom in 2016 is suspected to have been a contributing factor in a large scale horseshoe and blue crab kill in July. In this incident, an estimated 300 crabs washed ashore in the Assawoman Bay.

RELATED: Canyon sanctuary proposal off Ocean City dropped

PAST COLUMN: Macro algae now a major problem in our coastal bays

Lusk said the rapid decline in oyster populations since the 1950s is a product of disease and overfishing.

"What happened was there were a number of different oyster diseases that popped up that were killing off oysters, and we just kept fishing as if there weren't," Lusk said. "So, a lot of the oysters that held the disease-resistant traits they could've passed on were just fished out."

Oysters function essentially as natural filtration systems, sucking up water and pulling out potentially harmful nutrients. Their faltering populations have been notably seen in the Chesapeake Bay where, according to NOAA, oyster populations number less than 1 percent of what they were prior to bottom trawling's heyday.

However, the Chesapeake Bay's oyster decimation is not unique to the region, a point which Hawkins stresses adamantly.

"Everyone thinks of oysters as a Chesapeake Bay problem," Hawkins said. "But this is something that has happened across the coast, and is an ocean problem, too."

While commercial oyster dredging was banned by the state of Maryland in 2008, much of the damage had already been done, and the impacts were already well underway.

Sandi Smith of the Maryland Coastal Bays Program said the effect of oyster loss has become apparent in the northern bays, such as Assawoman.

"We, of course, don't have the pollution factors that the Chesapeake has," Smith said. "But there are still a very clear loss of oyster populations in the northern bays."

A murky future

While the rebuilding efforts, from volunteer services like the Ocean City Reef Foundation to state-funded projects, are becoming more commonplace, the delicate future of the coastal reefs is ambiguous. In tandem with efforts to rebuild, new threats arise in the forms of climate change and possible drilling endeavors.

"What oysters need right now is substrate," Lusk said. "Whether that be in the form of shells or oyster castles, these habitats for the oysters to grow off of need to be rebuilt in order for the populations to rebound back to what they once were."

However, the looming threat of climate change offers the possibility of throwing a wrench into the population rebuild plans. According to the Environmental Protection Agency, as carbon dioxide becomes more and more prevalent in the atmosphere, dissolved carbon dioxide in oceanic waters has the potential to devastate marine life, by way of making water more acidic.

READ MORE: Oyster reefs protect Assateague Bay from storms

READ MORE: Chesapeake Bay takes leap in health, report shows

The effect of higher acidity in marine environments has been demonstrated in the Chesapeake Bay, where low pH levels contributed to by sewage and other forms of pollution led to the erosion of oyster shells and substrate, according to a study by the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science. For cold water corals, a higher surface water temperature can lead to "bleaching," and inevitable death, further causing habitat losses for fish populations, according to the EPA.

An additional threat to deep sea corals rears its head in the form of the potential for oil drilling in the coastal deep sea canyons, such as the Baltimore Canyon off the coast of Maryland and the Norfolk Canyon off the Virginia coast. These canyons, two of 13 in the Mid-Atlantic Bight Region, have been considered for oil excavation. On Dec. 20, former President Obama signed an executive order that would bar oil excavation in any of these canyons across the Atlantic and Arctic.

However, President Trump has already reversed other oil policies on which Obama had formerly signed off. Specifically, the Keystone XL, formerly disapproved of by the past administration, now has now been expedited by the Trump administration. Additionally, another Trump executive order calls for expedited review of environmental impact on "high priority infrastructure projects," which can be presented by any senator or secretary, if the White House Council on Environmental Quality approves.

READ MORE: What will become of Chesapeake restoration under Trump?

READ MORE: Climate change funds: what will Trump admin do?

Lusk said that, while oyster populations may not be harmed by oil drilling, deep sea corals would be threatened.

"I would hope that if there were any oil drilling done out there, that they would follow a plan to be as safe as possible," Lusk said. "Oysters would probably be fine, but those cold water corals could really be hurt, especially if there's a spill. I would be really concerned for the loss of habitat."

Exploratory drilling in the Mid-Atlantic Bight Region was first conducted in the mid-1980s, but was later abandoned due to economic concerns. There are currently no active leases in the canyon.

Hope for the future

These concerns, though a fear for Hawkins, are not paramount. Instead, he aims to rebuild what he can — bringing back ocean habitats, one block at a time.

"He should be sainted for what he does," Ocean City Reef Foundation volunteer Beau Lyons said. "There's just not enough people out there who really want to make a difference."

Hawkins, with passionate fervor, holds up photos of pyramids he has built off the coast of Ocean City — once bare cement now teeming with life. He cites the specifics, from the Latin names of vibrant corals to a 1970s-borne project to curb mosquito populations by using discarded tires to build reefs.

Despite the complexity of his endeavor and the innumerable ecological, economical and historical factors that it carries along as baggage, Hawkins's ultimate goal is simple.

"I just want to make the ocean blue again," Hawkins said.

search_result.title: Rock-bottom rockfish numbers drag down Chesapeake Bay health ...
search_result.text:
Despite progress on pollution and habitats, the Chesapeake Bay has received another low health grade from the nonprofit Chesapeake Bay Foundation, this time due to issues with fisheries.

Results of the bi-annual State of the Bay report released Tuesday say the bay's health scored a D+ in 2020.

Though most water quality measurements are showing improvement, the bay's overall score was sunk by abysmal ratings on critical fisheries, including rockfish, oysters and shad.

Rockfish scored a 49 out of 100 on CBF's scale, which on its own qualifies as a C+ grade. But that score represents a decrease of 17 points since 2018, the largest decline in any single indicator CBF has recorded in over a decade, said Chris Moore, senior regional ecosystem scientist with CBF.

"Rockfish, often called striped bass here in the Chesapeake Bay region, are arguably the most important recreational and commercial fin fish we have in the Chesapeake Bay," Moore said in an interview.

Fisheries can be hurt by overfishing, habitat loss and pollution. In 2019, an assessment by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission showed rockfish were over-fished, and noted that the over-fishing was ongoing.

"One of the things that really concerned us about that (ASMFC) report is that the adult female striped bass, which are obviously most important to producing new populations of striped bass in any given year, had dropped approximately 40% between 2013 and 2017," Moore said.

More:'Historic' change to menhaden fishery management will consider ecological importance

In the next year, the commission plans to write a more comprehensive rockfish conservation plan, which will be key to restoring the population over the long term, Moore said. In the interim, states have responded to an ASMFC demand that rockfish catches decrease by almost 20%, including in Maryland and Virginia.

In August, the ASMFC enacted "historic" changes to the management strategy of Atlantic menhaden, a food source for many species, including rockfish. Revitalizing Atlantic menhaden populations will help restore not only rockfish, but also larger mammals and birds that like to eat them, Moore said.

Though efforts are underway to halt the decline, bold action is needed to ensure the species recovers because there is risk that states may simply settle for the status quo, CBF wrote in statement.

Health scores for oysters and blue crabs improved slightly since 2019, with blue crabs scoring a respectable B+ and oysters lagging behind with an F, according to the report.

Scoring the lowest of all, shad continued to decline with just 7 health points out of 100, a decrease of three points since 2018. The troubled fishery has been closed to fishing since the 1980s, and habitat restoration projects and efforts to facilitate fish passage to spawning sites have failed to help the population rebound.

Flagging fisheries will be helped by improvements to water quality and habitats.

In 2020, as nitrogen and phosphorus pollution to the bay improved, water clarity and dissolved oxygen numbers followed. Monitoring data indicated the 2020 dead zone — the annually appearing area of ultra-low dissolved oxygen that kills aquatic life — was one of the smallest on record.

More:2020 Chesapeake Bay dead zone second smallest on record

Progress on these issues has largely relied on pollution reductions at wastewater treatment plants and was aided in 2020 by favorable weather, the report states. To meet the goals of the Chesapeake Bay Clean Water Blueprint — a plan created in 2010 that aims to make all bay waters suitable for aquatic life by 2025 — more needs to be done, CBF says.

To meet the Blueprint's goals, efforts to reduce urban and agricultural pollution and suburban runoff need to accelerate, especially in Pennsylvania, which lags behind other states on this issue, the report states.

There is hope among Chesapeake Bay advocates that the incoming Biden administration will offer some solutions to the bay's restoration struggles through funding prioritization.

"The Biden administration can, as past presidents have done, utilize the bully pulpuit to put saving the Chesapeake Bay back on the national priority list, a list it was taken off of by President Trump," said CBF President Will Baker in an interview.

"Specifically, we'd like to see the Biden administration be a champion for allocating more federal Farm Bill conservation money to the bay in total, and to Pennsylvania specifically," Baker said. "But beyond that, it's critical that this administration undo the across-the-board environmental rollbacks — specifically to Clean Water Act and Clean Air Act provisions — that have literally pulled the rug out from underneath the states."

More action by individual states is also needed, the report concludes. Though Pennsylvania is most behind, other states like Maryland and Virginia must keep bay health a state priority, it said.

Maryland needs to take more effective measures to support striped bass and reduce its pollution from agriculture and stormwater through the addition of natural forest buffers, said Alison Prost, CBF's vice president for environmental protection and restoration.

“After decades of failed promises and missed goals, this year’s State of the Bay shows that the Chesapeake Clean Water Blueprint is working," Baker said in a statement. "Unfortunately, the stagnating score shows that we are witnessing apathy take hold and political will wane. We can still save the bay and deliver the promise of clean water to the next generation, but only if our elected officials redouble their clean water commitments and invest in finishing the job.”

Environmental watchdog reporter Julia Rentsch can be reached at jrentsch@delmarvanow.com.

search_result.title: Oyster aquaculture rebounding in the Nanticoke
search_result.text:
Rachael Pacella

rpacella@dmg.gannett.com

Before oyster disease hit the Nanticoke, a shucking house by the harbor was full of life and the shells that came from the factory went right back into the river.

Just like today's aquaculture, the shells went onto leases which watermen cared for and harvested from.

That was more than 60 years ago, and as the once packed harbor faded that shell stayed on the bottom, waiting and growing.

When Eric Wisner came to work at Nanticoke Harbor about seven years ago, he talked with the old-timers to find out where the old leases were.

"It was like searching for gold almost," he said.

When he was younger he spent his summers crabbing and working the water with his grandfather and uncle on the Magothy River in Anne Arundel County.

"Working on the water has always kind of been in the back of my mind," he said. "An enjoyable way to make a living."

There's no traffic on the water, and fewer phone calls. Wisner now leases about 1,000 acres of bottom on the Nanticoke River from the state. He made the boat he works off nearly from scratch, turning an old houseboat into a working oystering vessel.

To find the old piles of oysters on his leases he taps the bottom with a bamboo shoot.

"Tap, tap, tap. If you've got shell, that's half the battle right there," he said.

And if you don't have shell already on your lease, you can bring some in and start to build. Working with the state and nonprofits, Wisner is able to get spat - baby oysters - attached to shell, which he puts in the water to grow for harvest.

In addition to providing a source of fresh seafood for restaurants, the oysters filter and clean the water. The oysters Wisner uses are also reproducing, so they are helping to grow the Chesapeake Bay's oyster population as well.

A curse or a cure?

Assistance from state and nonprofit programs helped him grow his business, he said. He harvests oysters from the leases in the summertime, when prices are high, and uses the wild harvest season, which started a few weeks ago, as a time to take care of things on land, like painting boats.

In 2010, the state of Maryland passed a regulatory reform package which allowed the resurgence of aquaculture in the Nanticoke, and if the Army Corps of Engineers grants the latest round of permit requests — 63 additional acres for Wisner and 579 acres for Phillip Harrington — a patchwork quilt of leases along the Nanticoke would fill in.

Wisner said he thinks the resurgence of aquaculture in the river has created economic activity, from people who haul shell down to the river to the small store up the road selling gas and drinks.

"It's creating a product to harvest, and putting more people to work on the retail end," he said.

While oyster aquaculture in the Nanticoke is making a return, Keith Bradley of the Wicomico County Commercial Oyster Committee said it isn't a cure all.

"I don't see it replacing the public fishery," he said.

The public fishery employs more people, he said, and leasing public space for aquaculture could impact the wild harvest.

If you would like to comment on the 649 additional acres of aquaculture leases currently proposed for the Nanticoke, the comment period is open until Nov.1. Contact the Army Corps of Engineers through Eugene Morgenthaler at 410-820- 8629 or by email at eugene.j.morgenthaler@usace.army.mil.

search_result.title: Visa snag pinches Chesapeake crab industry
search_result.text:
Jeremy Cox

The (Salisbury, Md.) Daily Times

Troubles with the U.S. Department of Labor's visa program are causing ripple effects along the shores of the Chesapeake Bay.

Many seafood processors in Maryland and Virginia say they depend on foreign workers, mostly from Mexico, for seasonal labor. They pick crabs and shuck oysters, working under the agency's H-2B visa program.

But those processing facilities have been experiencing five- and six-week delays in bringing this season's workers on board because of holdups at the Department of Labor, they say. The issue has ramped up criticism of a program facing an uncertain future.

At the J.M. Clayton Seafood Co. in Cambridge, the 60 or so seasonal workers were supposed to arrive in time for the April 1 start of the crab season. When they didn't, Jack Brooks, one of the crab-picking house's owners, said he was lucky to find a few domestic workers to cover the work that had to be done.

House moves to tighten visa security

The company was dealt another stroke of luck when the chilly, inclement weather kept many watermen off the water. Still, the bureaucratic mess was exasperating, Brooks said.

“This is basically costing American jobs," he said, pointing to the statistic often cited by H-2B supporters that each visa granted supports four local jobs.

J.M. Clayton received its foreign workers about five weeks late. Since then, it has found itself taking on shipments of crabs from at least one rival that was unable to get them picked for a lack of workers, Brooks said.

The Obama administration only has itself to blame for the problems, said U.S. Rep. Andy Harris, who represents Maryland's Eastern Shore.

"Unfortunately this administration continues to try to kneecap this critical program by taking actions that hurt businesses across the Eastern Shore," he said.

A Department of Labor spokesman responded to an inquiry by pointing to a February press release.

A congressional spending bill last year increased the number of workers who could theoretically participate in the program, allowing visa recipients from each of the past three years not to be counted toward the 66,000-worker cap.

The Department of Labor implemented a 17-day "certification processing pause" to grapple with the changes, the release said. In the meantime, the number of applications it received during a three-week period in December and January doubled from the same span from the previous year.

To make matters worse, technical glitches with the agency's electronic filing system cropped up, lengthening the backlog.

The delays reverberated throughout the prized Chesapeake fishery. Watermen, particularly in Virginia, had no one to buy their freshly caught bushels. So, they simply stayed home.

“There’s plenty of crabs. You just can’t give them away," said Scott Wivell, a Cape Charles-based fisherman.

He reserves some of the blame for Virginia's crabbing regulations. The 2008 changes shortened the formerly year-round harvest, making the surviving crab houses dependent on foreign labor, Wivell said.

The visa program finds itself at a crossroads. Its biggest congressional benefactor, Sen. Barbara Mikulski of Maryland, is retiring soon. It's unclear what will happen without her in Washington, Brooks said.

“She’s the reason we continue to have workers here," he said. "She understands we just don’t have the local workers to do these jobs anymore, especially on a seasonal basis.”

search_result.title: Eastern Shore lawmakers unite to fight oyster harvest ban
search_result.text:
This story has been updated to reflect actions on Monday, April 8 in the Maryland State Senate after original publication on Friday, April 5.

Lawmakers in the Maryland General Assembly voted to override Gov. Larry Hogan's veto and permanently ban oyster harvesting in sanctuaries located in five Chesapeake Bay tributaries, including Manokin River.

The House voted to pass the bill over Gov. Hogan's veto on Friday and the Senate followed suit Monday morning.

Eastern Shore lawmakers voiced strong opposition to the bill, saying it would harm local watermen whose livelihoods depend on the oyster harvest.

"Of course we need oysters in the bay, it's the best filtration device there is," said Delegate Carl Anderton, R-38B-Wicomico. "But for us on the Lower Shore, we have our watermen, that’s our heritage. That's our way of life."

Environmental groups have pushed for the bill, saying that the sanctuary program is necessary and working.

"To save oysters we must use sound science to restore their habitat and protect them," said Alison Prost, Chesapeake Bay Foundation Maryland executive director, in a statement. "That’s what this legislation will do."

The oyster population across the bay has plummeted far below historic highs. A 2018 stock assessment showedthe number of market-size oysters in Maryland had dropped by more than half since 1999, to about 300 million.

It also showed that oysters had been harvested over the established threshold for the past three seasons in many lower shore regions.

"We’ve been watching the annual decline of the public fishery," said Don Webster, senior agent at the University of Maryland extension center. "I don’t see it really rebounding."

Five sanctuaries across the state — Somerset County's Manokin River, along with Harris Creek, Little Choptank River, Tred Avon River and St. Mary's River — would be permanently protected through the bill.

Millions in state and federal money has been invested in developing these oyster sanctuaries.

The legislation passed the House and Senate without the support of any members of the Eastern Shore delegation.

Hogan vetoed the bill late Thursday night.

"This bill is bad policy, is bad for our watermen — and worst of all — is bad for the Chesapeake Bay," Hogan wrote in a veto letter.

Watermen and scientists disagree on best policy

For decades watermen, environmentalists, politicians and scientists have butted heads over the state's oyster policy.

At the root is disagreement over how to best promote the growth of the oyster population.

Many scientists say that sanctuaries are necessary for oysters to reproduce on their own.

"It’s part of their survival strategy, you need dense aggregations of them to be able to spawn effectively," said Webster. "That’s what these sanctuaries were designed to do — they’ve done a very good job."

A recent study at the Harris Creek sanctuary found that the oyster reef established is able to filter the creek's total volume in 10 days during the summer months.

However, watermen argue that sanctuaries aren't effective. They say that periodical dredging would clear silt and sediment from the reefs and encourage oyster growth.

Dorchester County's Larry Powley pointed to the management strategy in Virginia as an alternative option.

Virginia allows watermen in the Chesapeake Bay to harvest oysters on public grounds on a limited basis every few years, in a program referred to as rotational harvest.

"They are increasing every year and in Maryland we are decreasing," said Powley, a captain who's been working on the water for 45 years. "What we’re doing is not working."

More:Oysters: Summer rain puts damper on harvest

More:Chesapeake Bay funding gutted in Trump budget: Eastern Shore leaders oppose cuts

Sen. Adelaide Eckardt, R-37-Dorchester, proposed an amendment to the oyster sanctuary bill in the Senate that would have required the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to develop a public fishery rotational harvest pilot program.

But the amendment didn't make it into the final bill.

"I offered multiple amendments to make the bill better but I do not think the bill is necessary," said Eckardt in a text message.

Scientists and environmentalists say studies don't support the theory that periodical harvests help oyster populations to grow.

"Many watermen are good environmental observers," said Webster. "They make observations and they form opinions. And opinions are not science."

Eastern Shore delegation strong support of veto

The Eastern Shore delegation unanimously voted to sustain Gov. Hogan's veto in the House and Senate.

From the floor of the House, they framed the issue as a case of urban Democrats disregarding the views of rural Maryland.

"They’ve basically ignored the will of the Eastern Shore representatives," said Delegate Chis Adams, R-37B-Wicomico. "At what point will the legislature really mean it when they say that we support local control?"

The Shore's sole statehouse democrat, Delegate Sheree Sample-Hughes, D-37A-Wicomico, broke ranks with the Democratic party to vote against the bill and to sustain the veto.

"The watermen have voiced their concerns to us," she said. "I'm from the Eastern Shore, I've always said that I have to maintain a stance for my convictions."

But she said she disagrees that the General Assembly neglects the needs of the Eastern Shore, citing other issues like education.

"We can't get everything our way," she said.

Several lawmakers said that they felt the bill ignored the input of their constituents through a collaborative consensus building processes, called OysterFutures.

The Cambridge-based stakeholder meetings lasted for two years and produced a series of recommendations for oyster management on the Choptank and Little Choptank rivers, including allowing hand tonging in some sanctuary areas.

Delegate Johnny Mautz, R-37B-Talbot, said he has heard from watermen in his district that they will be wary of participating in future discussions after the General Assembly acted against the OysterFutures recommendations.

But proponents of the bill said on the House floor that the some of the group's recommendations have already been ignored by the Maryland Department of Natural Resources.

Both Lower Shore senators, Eckardt and Mary Beth Carozza, R-38-Worcester, voted to sustain the veto in the Senate on Monday.

"We as the State of Maryland can meet and exceed our goals under the Chesapeake Bay Agreement without sacrificing the livelihood and way of life of our commercial watermen and their families,” said Carozza in a statement.

Do you work with oysters on the Eastern Shore? To share your opinion contact reporter Jenna Miller at jmiller@delmarvanow.com, 443-669-4005 or on Twitter @jennamargaretta.

search_result.title: Fires banned in 14 WNC parks; wildfires burning in 2
search_result.text:
Karen Chávez

kchavez@citizen-times.com

Fires including campfires are now banned at 14 state parks across the western part of North Carolina according to Mountain Region Superintendent Sean McElhone.

All fires, from campgrounds to picnic areas, are temporarily banned due to extremely dry conditions and the high risk of wildfire. Restrictions on campfires and cooking fires could be expanded to other parks on short notice, depending on local conditions.

Two wildfires are now burning inside state parks in Western North Carolina, including the Rumbling Bald area of Chimney Rock State Park in Rutherford County, and in South Mountains State Park in Burke County.

The Chimney Rock fire broke out Saturday night and is affecting the popular rock climbing area, which is closed to climbing and will be for the duration of the fire. The routes, bolts and structures should be mostly OK, McElhone said. The climbing area is about a mile from Lake Lure, where another wildfire is burning.

“Our goal is to protect the local community and then we’ll go in and do a full inspection after the fire is contained,” he said.

There is also an active fire burning in South Mountain State Park, which broke out Sunday night. The area burning is 150 acres and the park is closed, McElhone said.

“It is in the Chestnut Knob area of park, which includes the main access area of the park and the main trailheads. No structures or facilities are damaged, the park is closed for the safety of public, and will give our staff and N.C. Forest Service the chance to really attack and contain this fire.”

McElhone stressed that the burning ban pertains not just to campgrounds, but picnic areas and grills.

“We need to eliminate all fires. One of the biggest issues is people coming to visit our parks from other places and might not know about the fires. Our resources and those of the N.C. Forest Service are so strained. We’ve had crews from the mountain region, the Piedmont and the coastal regions. And many of these crews are just returning from the hurricane.”

Campfire bans are in effect at the following parks: Chimney Rock, Crowders Mountain, Elk Knob, Gorges, Grandfather Mountain, Hanging Rock, Lake James, Lake Norman, Mount Mitchell, Morrow Mountain, New River (including Mount Jefferson State Natural Area), Pilot Mountain, South Mountains and Stone Mountain state parks.

Cooking fires using propane and other approved camp stove fuels are allowed in designated areas.

Amber White, spokeswoman for Chimney Rock LLC at Chimney Rock State Park, said on Wednesday the attraction is completely open, including trails and amenities.

Campers and picnickers throughout the state parks system should be extremely careful with campfires and cooking fires. Use only designated areas for fires, do not leave fires unattended and use extra care to extinguish fires before leaving a campsite or picnic area.

Before visiting a state park for camping or picnicking, visit www.ncparks.gov for fire restrictions.

​Words by Ashley Breeding, Mona de Crinis, Joan Page McKenna and Dana Nichols

Desert Magazine

As the Joshua tree fronds begin to slump and the desert toad and its fellow critter friends go digging for shade, it’s a sign that summer is coming into full swing. While we’re fortunate to have such beautiful retreats as Joshua Tree National Park, Big Bear and Anza–Borrego State Park close by the rest of the year, this is the season to escape to cooler parks and other outdoor playgrounds. Here, we take you to some of the best recreation areas that our pocket of the country — well, Mother Nature in general — has to offer.

Cruising north on California’s Highway 1 — “PCH” among locals — from Laguna Beach to Newport Beach, you’ll pass a deep, craggy cove speckled with colorful beach cottages at one end, its 3-mile shoreline overlapped by aqua-green seas (or moody blue-gray waves, depending on the day). To the right, a verdant canyon juts from the roadside, its landscape traversed by sandy trails, its edge anchoring a cluster of ocean-view homes.

This is Crystal Cove State Park — a 2,791-acre swath of prime O.C. property, a cattle ranch back in the day, purchased from the Irvine Company in 1979.

Up close, the cluster of 46 cottages, with their palm-thatched roofs and vernacular makings, look like something from the past, and in a way, they are: A secluded spot that once went unnoticed to passers-by on the highway above, Crystal Cove first became a popular among Irvine Co. workers seeking respite, local plein-air painters (William Wendt is the first known to paint here) and silent movie–era Hollywood filmmakers scouting “island” locations. Eventually, the cove evolved into a small but eclectic community of settlers.

Crystal Cove Alliance, a nonprofit for California State Parks, has tirelessly raised funds for more than a decade to rebuild the ramshackle bungalows — all assembled between the 1920s and ’50s — replicating the materials used by the very “Covites” that fashioned them from found parts: lumber from a shuttered warehouse in Los Angeles, discarded interiors from the Hotel del Coronado, window panels from abandoned railway cars and even a wooden schooner that washed ashore in an angry storm in 1927.

The cottage restoration project called for three phases: The first two, finished in 2006 and 2011, included 29 of the historic cottages. The third is under way. Today, many of the charming structures are overnight rentals (plan to book far in advance, as the area’s endless summers put them in high demand year-round). A few serve as marine research facilities and educational exhibits for science lovers. You’ll also find The Beachcomber Café, Bootlegger Bar and Shake Shack here, all great places to dive into a tasty meal (or Prohibition-era cocktail) with an epic view.

Explorers of all ages will delight in the diverse species that dwell in Crystal Cove’s underwater park, observing the coastal tide pools and trekking the 17 miles of scenic trails. If you’re not able to reserve a cottage in time, or sleeping under the stars is more your vibe, two campgrounds are also available for tent camping. crystalcovestatepark.org

*The nearby Pacific Marine Mammal Center, which rescues and rehabilitates injured marine mammals, regularly releases them along the stretch of coast. If you’re lucky, you’ll catch a release on your visit. But you can also visit the facility for a tour and up-close look at these cute creatures.pacificmmc.org

Jutting out of the Pacific Ocean, within sight of the bustling Southern California coastline on clear days, Santa Catalina Island (popularly referred to as Catalina Island or simply Catalina) invites languid relaxation or non-stop action, depending on your mood.

Located only 22 miles southwest of Los Angeles, the island is the ideal weekend getaway for suburbanites and anyone else who needs some time away from the city scene. Part of the Channel Islands archipelago, Catalina offers ocean and land adventures including kayaking, parasailing, sea-trekking, biking, camping, zip lines and general meandering. Hiking the island is a popular pastime, from languid walks to strenuous jaunts for experienced hikers, such as the 37-mile Trans–Catalina Trail.

If you want to experience the fascinating world under the waves, get wet and explore the abundant marine life with a snorkel or scuba tank, or stay dry on a glass-bottom boat or undersea semi-submersible tour.

Enjoy a slice of California history and learn about the island’s colorful past, from serving as a stop for smugglers, pirates and other ne’er-do-wells to the eventual purchase in 1919 by the Wrigley gum dynasty of almost every share of the Santa Catalina Island Company in 1919 from the Banning brothers, original owners of the resort enterprise. The island’s storied past includes mining, stagecoaches, the Green Pleasure Pier, Chicago Cubs spring training, WWII military preparation site, Hollywood films, the creation of the Catalina Island Conservancy to protect the land and resources, and the art deco Catalina Casino perched at the water’s edge, which today holds a movie theater, ballroom and museum.

Avalon’s palm-tree lined main boulevard against the backdrop of the blue Pacific invites strolling, and bars and restaurants cater to the easygoing beach ambiance with open-air patios and terraces. Shop along the promenade for clothing, accessories and gifts, purchase island-style art at one of several galleries or succumb to the skilled hands of a masseuse at an Avalon day spa.

Paranormal enthusiasts will love a guided ghost tour through Avalon, built upon an ancient Tongva Indian burial ground. Learn about rumors of ghostly sightings, tales of scandal and unsolved mysteries and why the town remains haunted to this day.

Getting to this Southern California island paradise is easy: It’s approximately one hour by boat from ports in San Pedro, Long Beach, Newport Beach or Dana Point, or 15 minutes via helicopter. Staying there is easier still. Choose a charming bed and breakfast, beachfront hotel, cozy cottage or luxurious four-star country inn. For longer stays, or to get a feel for what it might be like to live on Catalina, try renting a fully functional condo and make meals at “home.” Whatever your goals or desires are in visiting Catalina Island, with so many options in activities, dining and lodging, you’re certain to find the mix that works for you. Just remember to bring your bathing suit or board shorts, tennies or hiking boots, and leave your worries on the mainland. visitcatalinaisland.com

*Engage your playful side on Catalina. Test your short game in a round of miniature golf or challenge your friends and yourself to a tech-driven scavenger hunt. All you need is a smartphone, curiosity and a quick, competitive mind.urbanadventurequest.com

Oddly shaped pillars of crimson rocks piled high like a giant castle constructed from dripping wet sand make southern Utah’s Bryce Canyon National Park one of Mother Nature’s most whimsical creations. Eons of erosion forced by frost wedging and the steady gnaw of rainwater since time immemorial have molded limestone into a brilliantly hued maze of slot canyons, windows and elaborate spires called hoodoos.

Stretching out, labyrinth-like, over more than 55 square miles, this sprawling reserve’s unique geology consists of a tangle of horseshoe-shaped amphitheaters carved along the eastern edge of Utah’s Paunsaugunt Plateau. Ponderosa pines, meadows and fir-spruce forests rich with wildlife skirt the plateau’s edge. At an elevation between 8,000 and 9,000 feet, the rim of Bryce Canyon offers panoramic views boasting some 200 miles of visibility. Crisp, pristine air and the welcome absence of large artificial light sources elevate stargazing from an activity to a spiritual experience.

Hiking trails wind through and above the almost otherworldly landscape, where color and light dance in step with the canyon’s rhythm. Travel the park’s main road at daybreak or sundown past the expansive Bryce Amphitheater, a hoodoo-rich depression lying below the popular Rim Trail hiking path, and stop at one or all of several overlooks: Sunrise Point, Sunset Point, Inspiration Point and Bryce Point. During the summer, the Bryce Canyon shuttle provides optional transportation to and from all of the points.

From Sunset Point, invest an hour and a half and walk the 1-mile, round-trip path along the rim of Bryce Amphitheater. Seasoned hikers who crave solitude can venture out on backcountry treks, such as the ambitious 22.9-mile Under-the-Rim Trail from Bryce Point to Rainbow Point. Stretch it out over a few days and pitch your tent at one of eight campsites along the trail. Find the hike that’s right for you: Pick up the park’s trail guide, determine your level and route your course. Exploring the park on horseback is another option during summer; inquire at the Bryce Canyon Lodge.

Two Bryce Canyon campgrounds offer sites for general camping. Traditional lodging is available at the Bryce Canyon Lodge throughout the season.

Check out the park’s visitors center and immerse yourself in the experience with ranger-led walks, tours and programs. It’s a great way to embrace the beauty while expanding your knowledge of this magical wonderland. nps.gov; utah.com/bryce-canyon-national-park

*If your idea of being star-struck has nothing to do with Hollywood, Bryce Canyon National Park offers stargazing programs, full-moon guided walks and an annual astronomy festival perfect for celestial-chasing paparazzi.

Long before Mormon pioneer John Wesley Powell first visited Zion in the 1860s during a scientific exploration of southern Utah, before white settlers discovered that the desert-like area’s rare geology and perennial river supported farming, indigenous tribes were hunting and foraging along the broad expanse of Utah’s Great Basin and western Colorado Plateau. Although sparse, evidence of these nomadic First People — baskets, flaked stone knives and and yucca fiber sandals — recovered from caves and unearthed sites dates back to at least 6000 B.C.

Today, Zion is federally protected as Zion National Park. The congressional bill designating the park was signed into law in 1919, making it the oldest national park in the state. Since then, park attendance has increased exponentially due to its distinctive rock formations, comfortable climate, a wide variety of flora and fauna, and a wealth of outdoor activities.

Wild sandstone canyons as narrow as they are deep, impressive plateaus, colossal sandstone cliffs in shades of pink, red and cream set against a sky of brilliant blue, lush hanging gardens and waterfalls courtesy of the plucky Virgin River, and attendant slopes laden with pine and juniper have earned Zion National Park a devoted following. Visiting only once in a lifetime is like sampling a single jellybean from a bowl brimming with limitless flavors.

Straddling three counties in southwestern Utah, the park boasts 229 square miles of unparalleled canyon country. With an elevation change of about 5,000 feet from the park’s highest point (8,726 feet) to its lowest point (3,666 feet), Zion’s diverse climate and topography nurtures an array of species and habitats, including 67 species of mammals, 200-plus birds and more than 1,000 types of trees and plants.

While Zion is truly beautiful to behold, it’s also built for outdoor adventure. Blessed with more than 90 miles of trails, 37 designated backpacking sites plus several at-large backpacking areas, and 124,400 acres of designated wilderness, the park is a backpacker’s paradise. Advanced planning and training are essential, and the study of the National Park Service’s Wilderness Guide is strongly advised prior to trekking into the backcountry. Wilderness permits are required for all overnight trips.

Bicycles are permitted on all park roadways and designated trails. A shuttle bus equipped with a rack that can accommodate two bicycles makes the journey that much easier, if you so desire.

The burgeoning sport of canyoneering has deep roots in Zion National Park. This adrenaline-spiking, synapse-sparking activity combines route finding, rappelling, swimming, hiking and problem solving. Zion has dozens of canyons ripe for exploring and slot canyons barely wide enough to accommodate a human body. The Narrows will give you a taste of what it takes to navigate a slot canyon. Fortunately, there are enough options to satisfy both beginners and those with advanced technical skills. Camping is allowed in three designated campgrounds: South and Watchman campgrounds are located in Zion Canyon and Lava Point Campground is about an hour’s drive from the canyon.

If it’s comfort you seek when retiring from the day’s activities, Zion Lodge on Zion Canyon Scenic Drive is open year-round and offers standard rooms, cabins and suites, as well as a gift shop and post office (888-297-2757 for reservations). While there, dine at Red Rock Grill or Castle Dome Café. Become a repeat visitor, and don’t deny yourself the chance to experience the many activities and nuances of Zion National Park. nps.gov

*Want to try your hand at canyoneering? Think “miner” and invest in a quality headlamp for those forays into tight spaces characteristic of slot canyons where the sun doesn’t shine. And prepare to get wet. Seasoned canyoneerers swear by moisture-wicking clothing (long sleeves are advised) and neoprene socks for optimal comfort.

California’s Sierra Nevada range brims with scenic beauty. Those looking to immerse themselves in it but not give up the vibrancy that humans contribute to the outdoor landscape — breweries, festivals, outdoor concerts, golf tournaments and organized mountain bike races — will find their paradise in Mammoth Lakes. About six hours north of Palm Springs, Mammoth is a happening mountain town that also boasts access points to the John Muir and Ansel Adams wildernesses. Crystalline lakes at upwards of 8,500 feet are recreational playgrounds for hikers and fishermen on cool summer days that rarely exceed 76 degrees.

Major highlights include the columnar basalt rock formation Devils Postpile National Monument, a 798-acre monument established in 1911 near the impressive Rainbow Falls, as well as Mammoth Mountain Bike Park, Sierra Star Golf Course (open to the public), June Lake fishing village and the country’s longest continuously running motocross race, which takes place every June. Grab a seat on a shuttle or drive 30 minutes to the eastern entrance of Yosemite National Park, where the picturesque Tuolumne Meadows are located. Before doing so, get your bearings on the region by riding Mammoth’s gondola to the 11,053-foot summit. The 360-degree view is a must-see, and you can opt to ride, hike or mountain bike down.

Adventurers will delight in making their own paths in and around Mammoth by both land and water. Choose from hundreds of hiking trails, varying in difficulty from easy nature paths to near-vertical ascents. Similarly, bike riders’ choice in trails range from gentle paved paths around town to road bike–worthy roads (south of town off Highway 395), to Mammoth Mountain Bike Park’s downhill and cross-country trails primed for the most fearless of fat tires. Interested in canoeing, paddleboarding or kayaking? Rentals are available around Mammoth Lakes Basin all the way up to June Lake. With campgrounds lining the border of most lakes here, it’s the ideal locale to pitch a tent — just a few steps from the cool waters.

An increasingly popular pastime in Mammoth Lakes is the showcase of outdoor live music, which can now be found almost daily in one of the village or lakeshore eatery settings. Festival-minded folks won’t want to miss the annual Mammoth Festival of Beers and Bluesapalooza every August, when bands and breweries gather under the pines for an entire boozy and bluesy weekend. Follow the festivities with a soak in one of the local natural hot spring tubs and you’ll feel like you wouldn’t want to be anywhere else.

*To a hiker perched atop the summit of Mammoth Mountain — or any other high point the eastern Sierras — Mono Lake is visible as the largest body of water in the region. This 760,000-year-old inland sea is a worthwhile stop for those driving Highway 395; while it looks stunning from afar, it’s even better up close. That’s because large tufa formations — limestone towers that loom overhead — line the shore, making the setting feel otherworldly. Walking trails are located at the South Tufa grove. Guided morning canoe tours are available on weekends in summer from the Mono Lake Committee, which also runs a gift shop and information center in the neighboring town of Lee Vining.

While the lake doesn’t have any fish, it is abundant with migratory birds, brine shrimp and alkali flies. Stop by the Forest Service’s nearby visitors center to see exhibits and learn more. Afterward, don’t miss the opportunity to try a hand-dipped chocolate soft-serve cone at Mono Cone.

Stand near the General Grant tree — a towering sequoia known as “the nation’s Christmas tree,” which holds court in a grove of other mammoth redwoods — and marvel at the majesty of nature. If the novelty of being dwarfed by the super-sized coniferous inhabitants of Grants Grove wears thin (and it won’t), there are natural wonders aplenty to keep the “wow” factor heightened. Arresting rocky vistas, deep valleys, vast caverns, fragrant forests and icy lakes carved from glacier bowls define the California wilderness duo of Kings Canyon and Sequoia national parks. Stretching across the southern Sierra Nevada range east of the San Joaquin Valley in elevations ranging from 1,370 to 14,494 feet, the tandem parks provide habitats for hundreds of species of wildlife, including skunks, black bears, bobcats, gopher, California king snakes, gray fox and the California newt.

With more than 800 miles of maintained trails in varying degrees of difficulty that traverse 800,000-plus acres of designated wilderness, hiking, camping and backpacking are among the most popular visitor activities. Wander through redwood groves on paved trails ideal for strollers and wheelchairs; learn about the diverse flora and fauna via guided ranger walks and programs offered by the Sequoia Parks Conservancy, as well as the parks’ visitor centers and museums; break bread with friends and family in one of the many picnic areas; or go Bonanza on horseback with your own steed or visit one of the pack stations. You can also submerge into the underground world of Sequoia National Park’s Crystal Cave (purchase tickets online at least 48 hours in advance) or, if you’re an experienced climber, scale the granite cliffs and domes; or venture deep into the wild with all you need for survival strapped to your back (wilderness permits are required for overnight adventures).

Drive one or all three segments of Generals Highway, from the Sequoia Park entrance to Cedar Grove and Kings Canyon, and absorb the parks’ remarkable scenery. Allow enough time to fully enjoy traveling the winding road from foothills to sequoia groves (vehicles longer than 22 feet are not advised on some sections due to road width). Stops might include Grizzly Falls, Roaring River Falls, Boyden Cave and Eleven Range Overlook, where on a clear day you can see California’s Coast Range on the other side of the San Joaquin Valley.

For optimum comfort, four lodges offer an alternative to sleeping in tents or under a canopy of stars. Wuksachi Lodge, in the Giant Forest area of Sequoia National Park, is a modern facility with 102 rooms, full-service dining, a cocktail lounge, and retail and ski shops (888-252-5757); John Muir Lodge is in the Grant Grove area of Kings Canyon National Park and offers 36 rooms and a restaurant. Or choose from six styles of cabins at nearby Grant Grove Cabins. Both facilities are approximately .5 miles from a sequoia grove, visitor center, market, restaurant, gift shop and post office (888-436-9615). Cedar Grove Lodge, open throughout the summer and fall, is in the Cedar Grove section of Kings Canyon National Park and offers 21 rooms, a counter-service restaurant, market and gift shop. The lodge is also within walking distance of Cedar Grove’s visitor center (888-436-9615). nps.gov

*Budding biologist must-do: Spread your wings working on a small animal project, such as surveying peregrine falcons for a week during the summer. Volunteer opportunities exist throughout the year.

Standing sentry over Morro Bay like a stoic guard at Buckingham Palace whose unflinching presence signals strength, safety and a sense of order in a chaotic world, Morro Rock is largely considered central California’s most prominent coastal landmark. Rising 576 feet above the waves and whitecaps of the Pacific Ocean, the rock is as environmentally and historically significant as it is an aesthetic natural phenomenon.

For centuries, mariners looked to Morro Rock, a 23-million-year-old volcanic plug, as a guidepost directing them on their journey. And American peregrine falcons make their homes high above the surf away from land-dwelling predators and curious humans, as the area is designated a natural preserve within Morro Bay State Park in San Luis Obispo County.

Morro Bay State Park features the Heron Rookery Nature Preserve, a lagoon and natural bay habitat that is a critical point along the Pacific Flyway stretching from Alaska to South America. More than 100 species of migratory birds stop here for seasonal roosting and feeding. Bird watching is one of the area’s most engaging pastimes; visit the Central Coast Birding Trail website (ca-ccbt.info) for birding locations, species information, resources and events. A nearby butterfly grove often hosts roosting monarchs from November through February.

Other popular activities in Morro Bay State Park include camping, picnicking, hiking, biking, geocaching, fishing and boating. If you’re a sailor at heart, you can rent canoes and kayaks from a small boat marina and grab a bite at the marina’s café after your seafaring adventure. The park is also home to the celebrated Morro Bay Golf Course, featuring a pro shop, café and driving range, all of which are open to the public.

Located approximately 150 miles south of San Jose and 175 miles north of Los Angeles, Morro Bay and surrounding areas enjoy mild summers and cool, often wet winters. Visitors are encouraged to keep sweaters and rain gear handy regardless of the season. morrobay.org

*Want to surf the waters near Morro Bay? Bring your wetsuit and maybe even booties, gloves and hoodies, as the temps are a far cry from Southern California’s endless summer.

Relaxing with great food and drink and enjoying the romantic vibe of California’s stunning central coast defines the charming seaside burg of Cambria. Galleries, boutiques, wineries, beachfront trails, ocean-view cottages, tide pools flush with marine life, preserves and Hearst San Simeon State Park 2 miles away make this area a truly remarkable getaway.

Nestled between Ventura and San Luis Obispo along iconic Highway 1, Cambria is an athlete’s Eden, a naturalist’s Shangri- La and an epicurean’s nirvana. Cyclists from around the world flock here for miles of renowned riding routes for all levels. Add breathtaking views, and even the most arduous training session becomes a sightseeing excursion.

Kayakers paddling in San Simeon Cove, directly across from the renowned Hearst Castle, might spot sea otters, elephant seals and possibly whales in the distance. Afterword, refuel with a deli sandwich from Sebastian’s, a favorite local eatery. Land trekkers find miles of trails and paths, most notably along the bluffs of Leffingwell Landing or at Fiscalini Ranch Preserve — 430 acres spanning across a mile of coastline. Bring your dog and your horse to the preserve: Both are welcome.

Animal-lovers won’t want to leave Piedras Blancas rookery, where elephant seals frolic year-round, mating and giving birth to their young during late winter and early spring. Other marine mammals that frequent the rookery include sea otters, dolphins and whales.

Keep love in the air with a visit to Moonstone Beach — Cambria’s most romantic stretch of coastline — where gentle, cool breezes refresh the soul and soft sand between your toes tickles all your senses. Find a moonstone for your beloved and keep the memory alive until your next visit.

Cambria also offers some of the finest accommodations and dining along the central coast, from elegant restaurants, family wineries and authentic delis to four-star hotels and estates-turned-bed-and-breakfasts. One of the area’s most popular events is the Annual Art & Wine Festival, where locals and visitors can win raffle prizes, watch artists hone their craft and, naturally, sample fabulous wine and food.

Easy to get to and impossible to forget, Cambria and adjacent Hearst San Simeon State Park are a magical vacation combination. parks.ca.gov

*Step into the past and glimpse the grandeur and romance of 1930s Hollywood with an evening tour of Hearst Castle and Hearst’s world-famous art collections. Docents clad in period attire lead you through 165 rooms and 127 acres of gardens, terraces, walkways and pools.

Yosemite captivates; it’s not a place you struggle to remember years after your family vacation. The rugged granite monoliths Half Dome and El Capitan, the bend of early morning light as it skips from rock to tree to water to earth, the deep solitude of Yosemite Valley, and the wild tumble of river water over Yosemite Falls seize your soul, and you are forever grateful for the hook.

Set in California’s scenic eastern Sierra Nevada mountains, many of Yosemite’s iconic vistas have been captured or reimagined by artists and photographers (most notably Ansel Adams), Hollywood directors and even tech mogul Apple, which named the two most recent Mac computer operating systems Yosemite and El Capitan, respectively.

Yosemite National Park’s inherent riches include towering ancient sequoias, expansive meadows, diverse animal and plant life, dramatic geology and abundant waterfalls. The tallest of its kind in North America, Yosemite Falls roars down 2,425 feet of mountainside in a chain of powerful cascades, one link mightier than the next.

A popular stop while visiting Yosemite is Tuolumne Meadows, a vast subalpine meadow ringed by rugged mountain peaks and glacially carved domes through which Tuolumne River quietly meanders.

For unparalleled sunsets, travel 16 miles of twisting road as it snakes up to Glacier Point. At this elevation, you can look Half Dome “in the eye” as the last rays of sun bathe the surface in soft hues of orange and pink. It’s also an excellent vantage point for viewing Yosemite Falls from above.

With more than 1,000 miles of designated wilderness in Yosemite National Park, there’s really not a bad seat in the house. Tunnel View is largely considered the most scenic and photographed spot in the park. Divinely inspired topography opens to the grandeur of Yosemite Valley with El Capitan rising tall on the left, Bridalveil Fall to the right and, appropriately, Half Dome commanding center stage.

Popular activities within the park include hiking on 800 miles of trails, biking 12-plus miles of paved bike paths, horseback riding (stock sites are available at some campgrounds), mountaineering, rock climbing, backpacking (wilderness permit required) and camping at one — or all — of Yosemite’s 13 campgrounds. In the summer, rafting along the Merced River is a popular pastime if the water level allows. Rent a raft or bring your own. Kayaks and other non-motorized vessels are also permitted.

There are a variety of lodging options in Yosemite National Park, from simple tent cabins at the High Sierra Camps to deluxe rooms at The Majestic Yosemite Hotel (formerly The Ahwahnee). Lodging is also available in surrounding communities. Learn about the area’s rich history and landscape at Valley Visitor Center, staffed by knowledgeable rangers, and Yosemite Museum, which highlights the cultural history of the native Miwok and Paiute people. Or immerse yourself in art at the Ansel Adams Gallery in Yosemite Valley near the visitor center and post office.

Whether you’re an artist seeking inspiration, a world-class climber and mountaineer, or a middle-class family on vacation, Yosemite National Park should be on every nature lover’s bucket list. travelyosemite.com

*Have a little Ansel in you? The Yosemite Art Center in Yosemite Valley offers art and photography classes and workshops all summer.yosemiteconservancy.org/yosemite-art-center

Snaking across the Sierra Nevada mountain passes, through fragrant ponderosa pines and past bubbling brooks, you might believe for a moment that the best part of a road trip to South Lake Tahoe is the journey there. But then you arrive: Coarse sandy beaches enveloped by towering Douglas firs run into rocky shorelines, breaking the tide of this majestic alpine lake (at a massive 191 square miles, it’s the largest in North America). Translucent green water flows into deeper … and deeper … and deeper hues of blue. Humbling mountains rise high from the distant shores, reflecting peachy pink light at sunrise and glowing golden in the evening hours. From dawn till dusk, this place is truly a spellbinding sight.

To experience the south end of Lake Tahoe — which straddles the California-Nevada state line — is even more arresting. Water lovers will revel in the many forms of exploration: kayaking, stand-up paddleboarding and boating are all common ways to cruise these waters. In some places, you can see as far as 70 feet below the surface. What you’ll find: wild fish like rainbow and brown trout, lake mackinaw and kokanee salmon. California gulls sweep overhead while the Canada goose is known to paddle alongside smaller boats in shallower waters. Low tide offers an expanse of sand wide enough for a leisurely stroll or to roll out a beach towel and relax with a good book. Pack a picnic and make a day of it; just be prepared to ward off the winged beggars.

Those who are thirsty for some fresh mountain air and an athletic excursion around the alpine wilderness have options aplenty: Desolation Wilderness features nearly 64,000 acres of pure beauty, from glacial valleys to Cathedral and Fallen Leaf lakes to grand granite peaks. Avid outdoorsmen who crave a challenge can hit the famous Tahoe Rim Trail (on foot or by mountain bike) for 165 miles of dirt along the ridge of the Lake Tahoe Basin. If you’d prefer to hit the path on four hooves, a few local stables will lead the way. Also consider a ride up the Heavenly Gondola (“limo to the sky”) and pull, swing and zip line your way across the breathtaking views. Keep an eye out for the region’s beloved black bear; mostly nocturnal, they have been spotted in the day.

When you need a rest, relax at your campsite — Camp Richardson and Zephyr Cove Resort are comfortable, traditional camping options — or hike to the 1920s for a tour of the Valhalla Historic Site or Vikingsholm castle, a 38-room mansion assembled mostly of materials found right here in Lake Tahoe. If you need a break from beef jerky and s’mores, local restaurants and pubs serve up a hot and tasty bite along with the wild ambiance. visitinglaketahoe.com

*The Lake Tahoe Outdoor Arena at Henley’s heats up this summer with performances by Sting and Peter Gabriel, Keith Urban, James Taylor and Steve Miller Band.tahoesouth.com



To dog lovers’ delight, most national and state parks — and some beaches — welcome your four-legged pals. If you’re road tripping with Fido this summer, be sure to check out these travel tips.

Always call ahead and go to individual destination websites for pet policies, rules and restrictions. Dogs might be required to be on a 6-foot leash or shorter, for example, and cannot be left unattended, especially in vehicles, which can overheat quickly and be deadly. Campsites may allow pets, but they must stay inside your tent/RV with you at night for their safety. (Remember to bear-proof pet food too!) Some park trails are off-limits, so plan accordingly.

» Bring your pet to the vet for a pre-travel checkup. Tell your doctor your destination and ask whether you’ll need to start your pet on heartworm or flea/tick prevention medications if s/he is not already taking them.

» Pack copies of your dog’s license, microchip number and vaccination records, including rabies, as well as photos and a physical description in case he or she gets lost. Keep them with you in a waterproof bag.

» Write your cell phone number in permanent marker on your pet’s collar.

» Carry a pet first aid kit and extra medications if needed. Download the American Red Cross’ Pet First Aid app at redcross.org/get-help/prepare-for-emergencies/mobile-apps or by texting “GETPET” to 90999. Look up the closest emergency vet clinic and store the number in your phone.

» Invest in a dog harness/seatbelt or crate your dog during the trip. Pets should ride in the back seat, as airbags can be dangerous for them. Don’t let Fluffy hang her head out the window when you’re on the road; debris can kick up and cause injury.

» Once you’re there, avoid any contact with local wildlife. Keep your dog on a sturdy leash or inside your vehicle with you at all times for his or her safety. Risks include animal attacks, snakebites, insect stings, disease transmission, falls and ingestion of poisonous plants/carcasses. If you’re not sure you can closely monitor your companion 24/7, it might be best to find a sitter and leave Fido safely at home.

» Know your pet’s physical limits. A full day at the beach or hiking in the heat may be too much. If so, leave her at home or at a nearby kennel for the day. (Some parks’ pet policy pages list local kennels.)

» Pack plenty of water and carry dog food with you. Consider purchasing a cooling vest, such as a Ruffwear Swamp Cooler, and cooling gel mats for warmer destinations.

» Be a good guardian and clean up pet waste.

» Schedule a post-trip vet visit to make sure your companion is healthy and parasite-free.

search_result.text:
A longtime effort to change the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area into a national park is stepping out of the shadows again and has picked up its first endorsement by a public body.

The Warren County Board of Commissioners unanimously approved a resolution last week endorsing the idea of Congress re-designating the nearly 70,000 acres of the recreation area as a national park and preserve.

As a "national recreation area," known by its National Park Service designation "DEWA," it would remain under the jurisdiction of the park service but move into the category of "national park."

The National Park System includes 423 individual units, with several in New Jersey, among them the Paterson Great Falls, Edison's workshops and the Morristown National Historical Park, with its four Revolution-era sites. Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty are also on the list and are shared with New York.

The system features two sections of the Delaware River and the Great Egg Harbor River.

Story continues below gallery

Among the 65 units that bear the designation of national park, there are just nine east of the Mississippi River, with just one, Acadia in Maine, in the Northeast. The two nearest to the region are the Cuyahoga Valley in Ohio and Shenandoah in Virginia.

In West Virginia, the New River Gorge National River, created as a National Park Service unit in 1978, was re-designated the New River Gorge National Park and Preserve.

The Warren County resolution said designating the recreation area as a national park "is to place this jewel of our national heritage into the crown of the national park system, where it has always belonged."

The resolution also said "upgrading the Delaware Water Gap would create greater awareness and prestige for our region. This could also mean more funding for maintenance, visitor amenities and other improvements as well as support the local economy."

During the meeting, Commissioner James Kern III said he met recently with Rep. Josh Gottheimer, Knowlton Township Mayor Adele Starrs, Committeeman Kevin Duffy of Hardwick Township and former Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area Superintendent John Donahue.

Outdoors:NJ is home to dozens of peaks above 1,000 feet, and they are all in North Jersey

More:Delaware Water Gap wants feedback on what to do with 500 historic buildings

Infrastructure:Delaware Water Gap roads to be renovated in spring as part of $21.5 million project

Contacted Friday, park spokeswoman Kathleen Sandt said DEWA officials, by federal law, cannot make any statements regarding the park designation movement.

However, she did write that a "change in designation alone may not impact these factors, but if the change includes additional lands and facilities, or results in a demonstrated change in visitation, that would be taken into account in future fiscal cycles."

She said the National Park Service unit's base funding "is provided through regular appropriations and is determined by the number of visitors, mission-essential activities, number and historic designation of facilities, acreage, road and trail mileage, if applicable, and other factors."

Sandt provided visitor numbers dating back to 1978, with a 2020 figure of 4.1 million, which would put the recreation area 10th on the list of most-visited units in the National Park System.

From 1998 to 2013, visitation was on either side of 5 million each year, but it dropped to a low of 3.2 million in 2018.

Visitation jumped in 2020 and 2021 because of the pandemic as people flocked to outdoor activities, such as kayaking, hiking and picnicking.

Sandt said there are 55 million people within a five-hour or less drive of the park.

In 2020, the park released numbers that show the 4.1 million visitors spent $144 million in local communities. That visitation and spending supported 1,970 jobs and contributed toward a total economic output of $212 million in communities within 60 miles of the recreation area.

The designation of the 70,000 acres as a "recreation area" is an artifact of the Tocks Island Dam project. Designed by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, the dam across the Delaware River at the head of Tocks Island would have created a lake that filled much of the valley northward to near the New Jersey-New York-Pennsylvania area.

The government bought and/or forced out the residents of what would have been underwater and around the shores of the proposed lake.

However, the 1960s project also birthed the environmental movement, as citizen activists fought the idea and eventually the federal government gave up the dam plans and gave the property to the National Park Service.

National parks, recreation areas, preserves, battlefields or historic parks must be approved by Congress.

Over the past couple of decades, there have been different efforts to make the water gap area into a national park. However, those efforts failed to gain much traction because, as a general rule, a designated "national park" prohibits hunting and fishing.

Any possible ban on hunting and fishing brought out most sportsmen and outdoors groups and tamped down support for a name change.

Many areas of Alaska and some areas in the western mainland U.S. carry the designation of "preserve," which allows for hunting and fishing, and last year, the New River Gorge National Park and Preserve was approved in West Virginia, marking the river itself as the national park and the lands beside the river as a preserve.

Donahue, the public face of the Delaware Water Gap effort, spent 38 years in the National Park Service, the last 13 years as superintendent at DEWA.

Among supporters of re-designation are the Sierra Clubs of both New Jersey and Pennsylvania and the Highlands Coalition. The organizers this week launched their own website.

Donahue described the effort as "a grassroots group of citizens" who believe the time is right to revisit the designation.

Travel:It's national 'Plan for Vacation' Day! Here's a few Pocono trips to consider

Commentary:Kulick: Do's and don'ts of hunting, hiking in Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area

Outdoors:Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area and Worthington State Forest hiking

Adventurer, beware: Why are abandoned resorts in the Poconos so thrilling?

He said the Warren County resolution was a first step and the group is planning to talk with county governing bodies in Sussex, Pike, Monroe and Northampton counties, as well as sportsmen's groups and other civic organizations.

Donahue said the working idea is for the term "recreation area" to be replaced, with some of the 70,000 acres designated as "national park" and the rest as Lenape Preserve.

"We don't want to make a final decisions of where park is and where preserve is," he said, adding that the working group's outreach is to get thoughts from other groups and tourism officials.

"This is a spectacular park," Donahue said. "You have the river, the Kittatinny [Ridge], the cliffs in Pennsylvania. There's 12,000 years of humans living here."

He said there is public prestige attached to the designation as a national park, but also, "We want to do this because it's the right thing to do."
